recipes.title: Freda's Old Family Casserole
recipes.description: Traditional hamburger and potato casserole with cream soup.

ingredients.item: cream of mushroom or cream of celery soup

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Sauté onions and peppers in a skillet (with shortening if using).
Add ground beef and cook until slightly cooked and in loose pieces. Do NOT brown.
Drain off all grease.
Add milk and cream soup to the meat mixture; stir to combine.
In a greased 2½-quart casserole, layer meat mixture, then potatoes. Repeat layers.
Cover with bread crumbs.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 1 hour.

notes: Spry was a popular vegetable shortening - can substitute any cooking oil or omit
Card notes 'do-mitted' suggesting shortening was optional/omitted
Complete instructions from both sides of recipe card

recipes.title: Impossible Cheeseburger Pie
recipes.description: Quick Bisquick pie that makes its own crust with ground beef and cheddar.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Grease a 9-inch pie plate.
Cook ground beef and onion until beef is browned; drain.
Stir in salt.
Spread beef mixture in greased 9-inch pie plate and sprinkle with cheese.
Stir remaining ingredients (milk, Bisquick, eggs) with fork until blended.
Pour into plate over beef and cheese.
Bake 25 minutes at 400°F (200°C), or until knife inserted in center comes out clean.

notes: Part of the Bisquick 'Impossible Pie' family of recipes
Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 960.jpeg

recipes.title: Pepper Steak
recipes.description: Classic pepper steak that can also be made with venison. Includes Grandma's note that she simmered it nearly an hour.

instructions.text: Heat oil in large skillet.
Cook meat until brown, stirring constantly, about 5 minutes.
Stir in water, onion, garlic salt, and ginger.
Heat to boiling. Simmer covered until meat is done. (Recipe says 12-15 minutes, but Grandma simmered nearly an hour for more tender meat.)
Add green pepper strips during last 5 minutes of simmering.
Blend cornstarch, sugar, and soy sauce together.
Stir cornstarch mixture into meat mixture.
Cook, stirring constantly, until mixture thickens and boils. Boil 1 minute.
Cut tomatoes into eighths. Place on meat mixture.
Cover and cook until tomatoes are heated through.
Serve over rice.

notes: Can substitute venison for beef
Grandma's note: 'I simmered nearly an hour' instead of 12-15 minutes
She used whole canned tomatoes

recipes.title: Eloise's Chicken Casserole
recipes.description: Layered chicken casserole with vegetables and a curry-mayonnaise topping.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Place green beans, broccoli, or asparagus in bottom of a deep casserole dish.
Add boned, diced chicken on top of vegetables.
Spread 1 can cream of chicken soup (or mushroom or celery) over chicken.
Mix mayonnaise with curry powder; spread over soup layer.
Sprinkle a little Parmesan cheese over top.
Add a few mushrooms on top.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 1 hour.

notes: Can use cream of mushroom or cream of celery soup instead of chicken
Curry powder adds a unique twist

recipes.title: Norma Lee's Liver
recipes.description: Baked liver and onions with BBQ sauce.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 325°F (165°C).
Dredge liver slices in flour.
In a greased casserole, place a layer of floured liver.
Add a layer of sliced onions.
Repeat layers until all liver is used.
Top with ½ cup BBQ sauce.
Bake at 325°F (165°C) for 20 minutes.
Remove from oven, turn liver pieces.
Top with another ½ cup BBQ sauce.
Bake another 20 minutes.

notes: BBQ sauce provides sweetness to balance the liver flavor

recipes.title: Homemade Beer
recipes.description: Simple homemade beer recipe using malt extract.

instructions.text: Dissolve malt extract and put in a crock or fermentation vessel.
Add water, sugar, and yeast.
Stir to combine.
Let set until it quits working (fermentation stops, no more bubbles).
Drain off and bottle.

notes: Historical home brewing recipe
Blue Ribbon malt extract was a common brand
Fermentation time varies based on temperature

flags: Very basic brewing instructions - experienced brewers should use modern sanitization techniques

recipes.title: Dandelion Wine
recipes.source_note: handwritten recipe card (partial - continues on back)
recipes.description: Traditional homemade dandelion wine with citrus and raisins.

instructions.text: Collect fresh dandelion heads, using only the yellow petals (15 quarts).
Place blossoms in cold water and simmer for 3 hours.
Strain the liquid and mix it with the sugar (15 lbs).
Let it boil well.
Strain through cheesecloth.
When lukewarm, add yeast and let stand for 2-3 days, skimming daily.
Simmer the juice of oranges (1 dozen) and lemons (½ dozen) with their rinds in a little water for half an hour.
Add the citrus mixture to the wine. There should be about 5 gallons total.
Put it into a cask and add raisins (2½ lbs).
Leave the cask open for a day or two.
Seal tight and let stand for 6 months.
Bottle the wine.

recipes.pan_size: large crock or fermentation vessel (5+ gallon)
notes: Traditional springtime wine
D.h. = dandelion heads
Requires 6 months aging before bottling

recipes.title: Norma Lee's Marinade
recipes.description: Asian-inspired marinade for grilled meats with soy, ginger, and wine.

ingredients.prep_note: or ½ cup vinegar + splash of wine
or 1 medium fresh onion, chopped fine

instructions.text: Mix together the ginger, sugar, dry mustard, pepper, and onion to form a paste.
In a separate bowl, combine soy sauce, wine vinegar, and water.
Blend the paste into the liquid mixture.
Pour marinade over meat and leave at room temperature awhile, spooning marinade over meat occasionally.
Refrigerate until ready to cook.
Remove meat from refrigerator at least 2-3 hours before cooking on grill.
Place on hot grill. Brown both sides fast to seal in juices.
Continue cooking, adding some marinade to keep meat moist and flavored.
Cut roast on an angle to serve.

notes: Grandma's note: 'I like wet pepper'
May save unused marinade and use on hamburgers or chicken within 2-3 days

recipes.title: Beef Jerky
recipes.description: Homemade oven-dried beef jerky with a savory spice blend.

instructions.text: Slice round steak into thin strips (⅛-¼ inch thick), cutting against the grain.
Combine all marinade ingredients (Worcestershire, liquid smoke, water, and all seasonings) in a large bowl.
Add meat strips to marinade.
Refrigerate and marinate for 12 hours.
Remove meat from marinade and pat dry.
Arrange strips on oven racks or dehydrator trays.
Bake at 150°F (65°C) for 8 hours or until dried but still pliable.

notes: Very low temperature dries meat without cooking
Can also use a dehydrator
Store in airtight container

recipes.title: Homemade Sweetened Condensed Milk
recipes.description: Quick blender version of sweetened condensed milk using dry milk powder.

instructions.text: Put all ingredients in blender.
Blend until smooth.
Use immediately or refrigerate.

notes: Oleo = margarine
Great substitute when you're out of canned condensed milk
Can substitute butter for margarine

recipes.title: Smoked Fish
recipes.description: Brine and smoking instructions for fish.

instructions.text: Mix water, salt, brown sugar, vinegar, and garlic powder to make brine.
Place fish in brine and refrigerate for 72 hours.
Re-mix (stir) the brine solution every 24 hours.
Remove fish from brine and pat dry.
Before smoking, sprinkle Lawry's seasoned salt on both sides.
Smoke until done.

notes: 3-day brining process for best flavor
Smoking time depends on fish thickness and smoker type

recipes.title: Spicey Mustard
recipes.description: Homemade honey-molasses mustard with brandy and wine.

instructions.text: Combine all ingredients in a large bowl.
Mix well until thoroughly combined.
Store in jars in the refrigerator.

notes: Makes a large batch - good for gift-giving
The brandy, wine, and vermouth add complexity

recipes.title: Homemade Shake & Bake
recipes.description: Homemade coating mix for chicken or pork, like the commercial product.

instructions.text: Combine all ingredients in a bowl or bag.
Mix well.
To use: Place chicken or pork pieces in bag with coating mix and shake to coat.
Bake according to meat type and size.

notes: Store in airtight container
Can use any type of crackers for crumbs

recipes.title: Duckling Apricot Stuffing
recipes.description: Sweet apricot stuffing for roast duck with thyme and nutmeg.

instructions.text: Combine dried apricots (quartered) with ½ cup water. Bring to boiling.
Cover and let stand 15 minutes.
Sauté sliced celery in butter or margarine until tender.
Combine celery with bread cubes, sugar, thyme, and nutmeg.
Add apricots (with liquid) and toss to combine.
Stuff duck and roast according to your recipe.
Fill neck and body cavity of a 4½ to 5 lb duckling that has been washed and drained.
Sprinkle cavities with ½ teaspoon salt before stuffing.
Place duckling on rack in a shallow roasting pan.
Roast in preheated 325°F (165°C) oven for 2½ to 3 hours, or until drumstick meat is fork tender.

notes: Recipe continues but rest not visible on card
Pairs well with roast duck or goose

recipes.title: Corned Venison
recipes.description: Home-cured corned venison using a traditional brining method. Can also be made with beef brisket.

ingredients.item: venison brisket, flank, or shoulder roast

instructions.text: Roll brisket or flank loosely and tie.
Place in large glass or pottery mixing bowl, or in a large oven roasting bag.
In glass or enamel saucepan, combine water and all remaining brine ingredients.
Heat just to boiling. Remove from heat; cool.
Pour cooled brine over meat.
Cover bowl with plastic wrap; or if using cooking bag, squeeze to remove air, twist and tie tightly in knot.
Refrigerate at least 4 or 5 days, turning meat occasionally.
Drain. Rinse meat with cold water.
To prepare corned meat: place in Dutch oven. Cover with cold water.
Heat to boiling; drain. Cover with cold water again.
Heat to boiling. Reduce heat; cover. Simmer until tender, 3½ to 4½ hours.
To make Corned Venison with Vegetables: add carrots, onion, potatoes, and cabbage about an hour before meat is done.

notes: Can substitute beef brisket for venison
Morton's Tenderquick helps cure the meat
Double-boiling method removes excess salt

recipes.title: Duck Apricot Stuffing
recipes.description: Variant apricot stuffing recipe for duck with slightly different proportions.

instructions.text: Combine water and apricots. Bring to boiling.
Cover and let stand 15 minutes.
Sauté diced celery in oleo until tender.
Mix celery with bread cubes, sugar, thyme, and nutmeg.
Add apricots with their liquid and toss to combine.
Stuff a 4½ to 5 lb duckling.
Bake at 325°F (165°C) for 2½ to 3 hours.

notes: Uses 1 lb apricots vs ¾ cup in the other version
Oleo = margarine
recipes.variant_notes: Uses more apricots (1 lb vs ¾ cup)

recipes.title: Rhubarb Pie
recipes.description: Simple rhubarb pie with egg-thickened filling.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Mix sugar, flour, beaten egg, and water together.
Let mixture set while making crust and cutting rhubarb.
Add chopped rhubarb to the sugar mixture.
Pour filling into unbaked pie crust.
Dot with margarine.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for about 1 hour until filling is set and crust is golden.

notes: Oleo = margarine
Can add top crust if desired

recipes.title: Rhubarb Cake
recipes.description: Easy rhubarb dessert using yellow cake mix with Jello and marshmallows.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Spread rhubarb in bottom of a 9x14-inch pan.
Sprinkle sugar over rhubarb.
Sprinkle dry Jello over the sugar.
Spread marshmallows evenly over top.
Prepare cake mix according to package directions.
Pour cake batter over marshmallow layer.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 1 hour.

notes: Strawberry Jello pairs well with rhubarb
8 tbsp Jello = about 1 large (6 oz) box
Marshmallows melt into the rhubarb layer

recipes.title: Italian-Style Golden Liqueur
recipes.attribution: Mrs. William A. Crain, Dade City
recipes.description: Homemade anise-vanilla flavored herbal liqueur, similar to Galliano.

instructions.text: Combine sugar and water in a saucepan.
Heat until mixture is clear and sugar is dissolved.
Stir in all 4 extracts.
Cool the mixture.
Blend in vodka.
Add yellow food color if desired.
Bottle and let mixture stand for 3 weeks.
Does not need refrigeration.

notes: Similar to Galliano liqueur
Great for Harvey Wallbanger cocktails
Makes an economical homemade version
Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 982.jpeg

recipes.title: Calamondin Liqueur
recipes.description: Florida citrus liqueur made with calamondins, a small sour citrus fruit popular in Florida.

ingredients.prep_note: carefully picked, stems removed, thoroughly washed

instructions.text: Put vodka and sugar in a glass jar with a flat, tight screw top.
Stir to dissolve as well as possible.
Add calamondins.
Seal jar tightly and leave on counter top (upright).
Next day, invert jar.
Repeat alternating positions of jar for 30 days.
Open jar, remove fruit, and enjoy.

notes: Calamondins are a small citrus fruit common in Florida
The daily jar flipping helps extract flavor
Can substitute kumquats if calamondins unavailable
Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 983.jpeg

recipes.title: Apricot Brandy
recipes.description: Homemade fruit brandy fermented with dried apricots and raisins.

instructions.text: Combine all ingredients in a large crock or fermentation vessel.
Let stand for 30 days.
Stir once a week during fermentation.
Strain twice through cheesecloth.
Bottle and store.

notes: 30-day fermentation process
Stir weekly to redistribute fruit

recipes.title: Norma Lee's Rum Slush
recipes.description: Frozen rum cocktail with tea, limeade, and lemonade.

instructions.text: Dissolve instant tea in hot water.
Mix all ingredients together in a large container.
Freeze for at least 24 hours.
Scoop into glasses to serve.

notes: Takes at least 24 hours to freeze properly
Slushy texture due to alcohol content

recipes.title: Gin Slush
recipes.description: Frozen gin cocktail served with 7-Up or lemon-lime soda.

instructions.text: Boil water and sugar together until clear and sugar is dissolved.
Add frozen orange juice and lemonade concentrates; stir to combine.
Add gin and mix well.
Pour into container and freeze.
To serve: Scoop ¾ cup slush into a glass and fill with 7-Up or similar soda.

notes: The alcohol keeps it slushy
Can also use Sprite or other lemon-lime sodas

recipes.title: Frozen Daiquiris
recipes.description: Quick blender daiquiris using frozen lemonade. Includes strawberry variation.

instructions.text: Put frozen lemonade, rum, and sugar in blender.
Fill blender with broken ice cubes.
Blend for a few seconds until slushy.
Serve immediately.

notes: Strawberry variation: Add 1 package frozen strawberries, 1 can lemonade, 1 can light rum, and ice cubes. Blend.
Using the empty lemonade can to measure rum gives perfect proportions

recipes.title: Marg's Cherry Pie
recipes.description: Cherry pie with a coconut crumb crust - half on bottom, half on top.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).
Mix flour, oleo, and sugar together well until crumbly.
Add coconut and mix to combine.
Use half the mixture for the bottom crust, pressing into a lightly greased pan.
Add cherry pie filling over the crust.
Sprinkle remaining crumb mixture over the cherries.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 30 minutes.

notes: Crumb-style pie rather than traditional crust
Oleo = margarine

recipes.title: Mary Meade's Holiday Eggnog
recipes.description: Classic brandy and rum eggnog with whipped cream and beaten egg whites folded in.

instructions.text: Beat egg yolks until thick and light.
Add sugar gradually, beating constantly.
Still beating, gradually add the brandy and rum.
Chill for an hour, stirring occasionally.
Add milk slowly and fold in whipped cream.
Beat egg whites until stiff and fold in.
Store in covered jars in the refrigerator for a day or so, if possible, before serving.
Serve from punch bowl; ladle the nog into the punch bowl as you serve it (otherwise, you'll get too much fluff on one serving and not enough on the next).
Provide nutmeg for guests to shake over the eggnog themselves.

notes: Variation: Replace 1 cup of the brandy with 1 cup orange liqueur
Best if made a day ahead
Image restored - contains handwritten "½C" annotation modifying sugar amount

recipes.title: Colonial Orange Eggnog
recipes.description: Festive orange-flavored eggnog with ice cream and ginger ale.

instructions.text: Beat sugar, cinnamon, ginger, and cloves into eggs.
Stir in orange juice.
Cut ice cream into small chunks and place in chilled punch bowl.
Pour ginger ale into bowl against the sides.
Add egg and juice mixture slowly, stirring gently.
Sprinkle with nutmeg. Serve immediately.

notes: Non-alcoholic option
Best served immediately while ice cream is still chunky
Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 991.jpeg

recipes.title: Fish Marinade for Smoking
recipes.description: Brine marinade for smoking fish, similar to the earlier smoked fish recipe.

instructions.text: Mix water, salt, brown sugar, vinegar, and garlic powder.
Place fish in brine and soak for 72 hours.
Stir/mix the brine 3 times during soaking.
Before smoking, season both sides with seasoned salt.
Smoke fish until done.

notes: Larger batch than the other smoked fish recipe
3-day brining for best results
recipes.variant_notes: Larger batch with slightly different proportions

recipes.title: Brown Bread
recipes.description: Quick brown bread with raisins, dates, and nuts using sour milk.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 325°F (165°C).
Mix dry ingredients together.
Beat egg with sour milk.
Combine wet and dry ingredients.
Fold in raisins, dates, and nuts.
Pour into 2 small greased loaf pans.
Bake at 325°F (165°C) for about 35 minutes.

notes: Brown flour = whole wheat flour
Sour milk can be made by adding 1 tbsp vinegar to regular milk

recipes.title: Boston Brown Bread
recipes.description: Traditional steamed Boston brown bread baked in coffee cans with molasses and cornmeal.

ingredients.prep_note: with 1 tsp soda dissolved in it

instructions.text: Grease 2 coffee cans and their lids.
Mix egg, sugar, and molasses together.
Dissolve baking soda in sour milk.
Combine cornmeal, graham flour, all-purpose flour, baking powder, and salt.
Add lard/shortening.
Alternate adding sour milk mixture with flour mixture.
Fold in raisins, nuts, and currants.
Pour into prepared coffee cans; cover with lids.
Bake with covers on for 1½ hours.
Remove covers and bake 15 minutes more to brown tops.

notes: Traditional New England steamed bread
Coffee can method creates round slices perfect for sandwiches

recipes.title: Brown Bread
recipes.description: Brown bread made with graham flour and buttermilk.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Blend molasses, brown sugar, egg, and salt.
Add soda to flour.
Alternate adding buttermilk with flour mixture to the molasses mixture.
Lightly fold in raisins and 1 cup chopped nuts if desired.
Pour into greased loaf pans.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 45 minutes for large pans.

recipes.pan_size: 2 loaf tins or 3 small loaf pans
notes: Graham flour gives a nutty, wholesome flavor
Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 999.jpeg

recipes.title: Crazy Cake with Fudge Frosting
recipes.description: Grandma Baker's signature depression-era chocolate cake (also called Wacky Cake) topped with peanut butter and fudge frosting. A family tradition!

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Mix flour, sugar, cocoa, baking soda, and salt in a 9x13 pan.
Make 3 wells in the dry ingredients.
Add vinegar in one well, oil in another, and vanilla in the third.
Pour water over all and beat until smooth.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 25-30 minutes.
Let cool slightly, then spread a generous layer of peanut butter over the warm cake.
Top with fudge frosting (recipe follows).

notes: Also known as 'Wacky Cake' - a depression-era recipe with no eggs, butter, or milk
Grandma Baker's tradition: spread peanut butter on warm cake, then pour fudge frosting over
The 3-minute fudge recipe is in MomMom Baker's collection

recipes.title: Fudge Frosting
recipes.source_note: handwritten recipe card (on Crazy Cake card)
recipes.description: Quick-cooked fudge frosting to pour over Crazy Cake with peanut butter.

instructions.text: Combine sugar, cocoa, milk, butter, and salt in a saucepan.
Bring to a full boil.
Boil for 1½ minutes (or 3 minutes for thicker fudge).
Remove from heat.
Add vanilla and beat to spreading consistency.
Pour over peanut butter layer on cake while still warm.

notes: Pour over peanut butter layer while frosting is still pourable
Double recipe and cook 3 minutes for standalone fudge

recipes.title: No Bake Oatmeal Fudge Cookies
recipes.description: Classic no-bake cookies with chocolate, peanut butter, and oatmeal. Labeled as the 'Best recipe'!

instructions.text: Combine sugar, milk, cocoa, and salt in a saucepan.
Bring to a boil and boil for 1 minute (or to soft ball stage).
Remove from heat.
Add butter, oatmeal, peanut butter, and vanilla.
Mix until well blended.
Drop by teaspoonfuls onto wax paper.
Let cool and set before serving.

notes: Labeled 'Best recipe' on original card
Crunchy peanut butter adds texture
Work quickly - mixture sets fast

recipes.title: Shortbread Cookies
recipes.description: Classic 3-ingredient shortbread cookies - simple and buttery.

instructions.text: Mix soft butter with sugar until well combined.
Stir in flour and mix well.
Chill dough until firm.
Roll out to ⅓ inch thickness.
Cut out cookies with desired shapes.
Bake at 300°F (150°C) for 20 minutes. Do not let brown.

notes: Low temperature prevents browning for traditional pale shortbread
Add ¼ tsp baking powder if making into pop tarts

recipes.title: Johnny Cake
recipes.description: Traditional cornmeal quick bread, also known as johnnycake or journey cake.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Grease a 9-inch square pan.
Mix dry ingredients together (cornmeal, flour, sugar, salt, baking powder, soda).
Cut in lard until mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Beat egg with sour milk.
Add wet ingredients to dry and stir just until combined.
Pour into prepared pan.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 25-30 minutes until golden.

notes: Traditional New England/Southern quick bread
Sour milk = buttermilk or milk with 1 tbsp vinegar

recipes.title: French Onion Soup
recipes.description: Classic French onion soup with caramelized onions, beef broth, and Gruyère cheese.

instructions.text: In heavy 4- to 6-quart pot, melt butter; add oil.
Stir in onions; cover and cook 15 minutes until onions are completely wilted.
Uncover pot; stir in salt, sugar, and pepper.
Increase heat to moderately high. Cook onions 30 to 40 minutes, stirring every 2-3 minutes and scraping bottom of pot until onions are nutty brown.
Sprinkle browned onions with flour and stir thoroughly until smooth.
Slowly pour in 2 cans of the broth, stirring constantly.
When well blended, add remaining broth and wine; partially cover pot and simmer over moderately low heat for 1½ hours.
May be refrigerated and later reheated.
To serve: Ladle into 6 heat-proof bowls. Arrange thin slice of French bread on top of each and sprinkle with cheese.
Bake in preheated 375°F (190°C) oven for 20 minutes.
Then broil for 3-5 minutes until cheese is lightly browned.

notes: Proper caramelization of onions is key - don't rush it
Can make soup ahead and reheat

recipes.title: Rick's French Onion Soup
recipes.description: Crock pot version of French onion soup for easy preparation.

instructions.text: In large skillet, cook onions in butter until lightly browned. (Allow enough preparation time for this.)
In crock pot, combine browned onions with cooking butter, bouillon, water, Worcestershire sauce, and salt.
Cover; cook on low for 4 to 5½ hours.
Place 3 slices of Swiss cheese on top of the liquid in the crock pot.
Cook 20 to 30 minutes more.
Add a few more Swiss cheese slices shortly before serving.
Place slices of toasted French bread in 4 soup bowls.
Top each with a slice of cold Swiss cheese.
Stir soup in crock pot and ladle over bread. Serve immediately.

notes: Recipe may be doubled and kept hot in slow-cooking pot
The layering of cheese at different stages creates great texture

recipes.title: Chicken and Cabbage Panade
recipes.description: Layered casserole of chicken, cabbage, bread, and cheese - a panade is a bread-thickened dish.

ingredients.prep_note: boneless, skinless, cut into thin strips

instructions.text: Heat oven to 350°F (175°C).
In a large skillet, melt butter over medium-high heat (add a little oil, less butter to prevent scorching, or substitute margarine).
Add cabbage, carrots, onions and raw chicken. Cook and stir until vegetables are tender and chicken no longer pink.
Place 4 slices of French bread in bottom of ungreased 2½- to 3-quart casserole.
Spoon half of cabbage mixture over bread; sprinkle with 1 tablespoon of the Parmesan cheese.
Repeat with 4 slices of bread, remaining cabbage mixture and 1 tablespoon of the Parmesan.
Top with remaining bread. Pour chicken broth over bread and cabbage mixture.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 20 minutes.
Sprinkle with Swiss cheese and remaining 1 tablespoon Parmesan.
Bake 20-25 minutes more or until edges are bubbly.
Serve in soup bowls with knife, fork and spoon for each diner.

notes: A panade is a traditional bread-based casserole
Serve with utensils - it's a knife-and-fork dish

recipes.title: Crispy Parmesan Tenders
recipes.description: Crispy baked chicken tenders coated in Parmesan and buttery crackers.

instructions.text: Heat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Line a rimmed baking sheet with foil and spray with non-stick cooking spray.
Rinse chicken with cold water and pat dry with paper towels.
Pour oil into a shallow dish.
In a separate shallow dish, combine finely crushed cracker crumbs, Parmesan, and garlic powder.
Dip chicken tenderloins (or chicken breasts cut into long portions) into the oil one at a time, letting excess drip back into dish.
Roll each piece in the crumb mixture.
Arrange coated tenderloins in a single layer on the prepared baking sheet.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 20-25 minutes or until done.
Serve chicken strips with a dipping sauce of choice, such as Kraft's bottled sweet & sour sauce.

notes: The only recipe not from the new Pillsbury cookbook mentioned in the article
Great kid-friendly dinner

recipes.title: Chinese Chicken Tacos
recipes.description: Asian-inspired tacos with ginger-soy chicken and cabbage.

instructions.text: Spray a large non-stick skillet with non-stick cooking spray.
Heat over medium-high heat until hot.
Add chicken, ginger and garlic. Cook and stir 3 to 5 minutes, or until lightly browned.
Reduce heat to low.
Add soy sauce, honey, green onion and crushed red pepper flakes; stir to coat.
Cover; cook over low heat for 5 minutes, or until chicken is no longer pink, stirring occasionally.
To serve, place scant ¼ cup chicken in each taco shell, and tuck in lots of shredded iceberg lettuce or napa cabbage.

notes: Menu suggestion: Serve two or three tacos per dinner plate with egg drop soup topped with lots of green onion slices and a scoop of hot rice mixed with tiny thawed peas, a pinch of golden turmeric or curry powder and a spoonful of sweet & sour dressing or bottled sweet & sour sauce.

conversions.conversion_notes: Flag corrected: no metric conversions available

recipes.title: Brown Sugar Apple Crumb Pie
recipes.source_note: newspaper clipping (from The Artful Pie: Unforgettable Recipes for Creative Cooks, 1993)
recipes.description: Double-crust apple pie with a brown sugar crumb crust and buttery topping.

ingredients.prep_note: firm, tart, will hold shape when baked
cut into small pieces, for crust
cut into small pieces, for topping

instructions.text: For filling: In a large, non-aluminum saucepan, stir together the lemon juice, water and brown sugar.
Peel, core and slice the apples. Stir the apples into the lemon and sugar mixture.
Stir in the raisins. Place the saucepan over medium heat and cook until the apples are tender, about 5 to 6 minutes. Stir them occasionally and gently as they cook.
For crumb crust: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).
Thoroughly butter the sides and bottom of a 10-inch pie pan.
In a medium mixing bowl, stir together the all-purpose flour, whole-wheat flour, brown sugar and salt.

Use a pastry blender to cut the butter into the dry ingredients until the butter pieces are the size of small peas. This may also be done in an electric mixer on the lowest speed, but be careful not to overmix.
Cut the egg yolk into the crumb mixture until it is evenly distributed.
Assembly and baking: Set aside 1 cup of the crumb mixture.
Press the remaining crumb mixture into the bottom and sides of the prepared pie pan.
Spoon the apples into the crumb-lined pan and pat them down lightly.
Sprinkle the reserved cup of crumbs over the apples.
Dot the top of the pie with the butter pieces.
Bake until bubbling and brown on top, 50 to 55 minutes.
Serve warm or cool.

notes: From The Artful Pie cookbook (Chapters, 1993; $24.95)
Use firm tart apples that hold their shape

recipes.title: Creamy Linguini with Bacon and Peas
recipes.attribution: Charlotte Balcomb Lane, Knight-Ridder News Service
recipes.description: Creamy pasta with bacon, peas, and Parmesan in a light evaporated milk sauce.

instructions.text: Cook the pasta according to package directions. When tender, drain thoroughly and set aside.
While the pasta is cooking, fry the bacon over medium heat in a large nonstick skillet until crisp and brown.
Remove the bacon to paper towels and blot thoroughly.
Discard all but 1 tablespoon of the grease. (You may discard all the bacon grease and substitute 1 tablespoon olive or corn oil in its place.)
Cook the onion, garlic and mushrooms in the grease or oil until the vegetables are soft and slightly brown, about 5 minutes.
Remove the vegetables from the skillet and set aside.
In a small dish, combine the flour, salt, basil, white pepper and nutmeg.
Add the 1 teaspoon of olive oil to the skillet and heat over medium-low heat.
Sprinkle the flour mixture over the oil and stir with a wire whisk or a slotted spoon for 1 minute until the flour is slightly toasted in the oil.
Pour the evaporated skim milk into the skillet, stirring constantly to prevent lumps from forming. (If lumps form, don't worry, just keep stirring.)
Cook until the mixture comes to a boil and thickens.
Stir the bacon and vegetables into the sauce, then add the peas, lemon juice and Parmesan cheese.
Cook over low heat 2-3 minutes, then stir in the cooked pasta.
If sauce is too thick, thin with 1-2 tablespoons of water or regular skim milk.

notes: Nutritional information per serving: 304 calories, 8.5 gm. fat (25% of calories from fat), 12 gm. protein, 46 gm. carbohydrate, 6 mg. cholesterol, 338 mg. sodium

recipes.title: Vidalia Onion Dip
recipes.attribution: 1989 Vidalia Onion Cookoff Grand Prize Winner
recipes.description: Award-winning sweet onion dip - grand prize winner at the 1989 Vidalia Onion Cookoff.

instructions.text: Peel and thinly slice the onions.
Soak for 2 to 4 hours in the sugar, vinegar, and water mixture.
Drain well.
Toss with mayonnaise and celery salt.
Serve on saltine crackers. Also great with hot dogs and hamburgers.

notes: Grand Prize Winner - 1989 Vidalia Onion Cookoff, Glennville, GA
The sugar-vinegar soak mellows the onions

recipes.title: Vidalia Onion Classic Casserole
recipes.description: Creamy Vidalia onion casserole with sherry and two cheeses.

instructions.text: Sauté sweet onions in butter until they are transparent.
Add chicken broth, sherry and flour. Cook and stir until slightly thickened.
Transfer to a medium casserole.
Top with bread crumbs and both cheeses.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 20 to 30 minutes or until lightly browned and bubbly.
May be prepared ahead of time and refrigerated, then baked.

notes: Can be made ahead and refrigerated before baking

recipes.title: Vidalia Cheese Wafer
recipes.description: Sharp cheddar cheese crackers with Vidalia onion and a hint of cayenne.

instructions.text: In large mixing bowl, blend grated Cheddar with flour, Parmesan, seasoned salt, butter (cut in bits), diced sweet onion and cayenne.
Blend well by beating with a wooden spoon or mixer.
Form dough into two rolls; wrap in plastic wrap.
Place in freezer 30 minutes or fridge for a couple of hours.
Slice into wafers about ¼-inch thick.
Space close together, but not touching, on an ungreased baking sheet.
Bake one sheet at a time at 375°F (190°C) for about 15 minutes, or just until done.

notes: Can freeze dough logs for later use
Great appetizer crackers

recipes.title: Broccoli Stuffed Baked Vidalias
recipes.description: Vidalia onion halves stuffed with broccoli and topped with cream cheese sauce.

instructions.text: Peel and halve onions. Parboil in salted water 12 minutes; drain.
Meanwhile, microwave or briefly cook the broccoli and drain well.
Remove onion centers, leaving ¾-inch-thick shells.
Chop center portions to equal 1 cup.
Combine broccoli with chopped onions, Parmesan, mayo and lemon juice. Spoon into centers of onion halves.
For sauce, melt the butter in a small saucepan and blend in flour and salt.
Gradually whisk in milk and cook until thick, stirring constantly.
Remove from heat and blend in cream cheese.
Spoon sauce over onion halves and bake, uncovered, at 375°F (190°C) for 20 minutes.

notes: From the Bland Farms Vidalia Onion Cookbook

conversions.conversion_notes: Flag corrected: no metric conversions available

recipes.title: Onion Squares
recipes.description: Savory biscuit-based squares topped with sautéed onions and sour cream.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).
Blend 1 egg and milk with biscuit mix and poppy seeds.
Turn dough into a greased 9-inch square baking pan.
Sauté onions in butter until tender.
Spread onions on dough.
Beat the other egg with sour cream and season with salt and pepper.
Spread sour cream mixture over onions.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 25 minutes.
Cut into squares. Sprinkle with paprika.

notes: From Bland Farms, Glennville, GA - home of Vidalia onions

conversions.conversion_notes: Flag corrected: no metric conversions available

recipes.title: Libby's Outrageous Onion Cake
recipes.source_note: newspaper clipping (First place winner, onion festival)
recipes.description: Unexpected chocolate cake made with pureed Vidalia onion - first place winner at the onion festival!

instructions.text: Empty cake mix into the large bowl of an electric mixer. Add the eggs.
Puree the diced onion with the oil in a blender.
Add pureed onion mixture to the cake mix bowl and beat until a smooth cake batter forms.
Bake in two greased-and-floured 9-inch round cake pans at 325°F (165°C) for 25 minutes or until done.
Cool and split layers.
Fill with strawberry preserves.
Mix canned chocolate icing with powdered sugar, shortening (Crisco specified by Libby) and water.
Beat at high speed of an electric mixer until the frosting is light and fluffy.
Spread over the top and sides of cake.
Decorate as desired, choosing strawberry slices and/or chocolate shavings.

notes: First place winner at onion festival
Libby is a member of the onion-growing Bland family
The onion adds moisture - you can't taste it!

conversions.conversion_notes: Flag corrected: no metric conversions available

recipes.title: Orange-Flavored Beans with Tofu
recipes.description: Healthy Asian-inspired stir-fry with tofu, green beans, and orange sauce.

instructions.text: Prepare brown rice according to package directions; keep warm.
While rice is cooking, mix orange juice, red-pepper flakes, ginger, honey, soy sauce, garlic and rice vinegar in glass measuring cup.
Drain tofu; press gently with paper toweling to remove any excess moisture. Cut into ½-inch cubes.
Place tofu in 8x8-inch glass dish. Pour half of orange juice mixture over tofu; cover with plastic wrap; refrigerate to marinate for 20 minutes.
Meanwhile, bring large pot of water to boiling. Add green and yellow beans; cook for 3 to 4 minutes or until crisp-tender. Drain.
Using knife, remove rind and bitter white pith from orange. Section, removing membranes and seeds. Cut sections into pieces.
Heat oil in large skillet over medium-high heat. Add beans and red pepper; sauté 5 minutes.
Add remaining orange juice mixture; cook another 3 minutes.
Remove tofu with slotted spoon from marinade and add to skillet; reserve marinade in dish. Stir orange pieces into skillet.
Whisk cornstarch into marinade in glass dish until smooth.
Stir into skillet; cook, stirring occasionally, until sauce thickens and clears, about 3 minutes.
Serve with brown rice. Sprinkle with green onion.

notes: FC Good Food - Pick of the Crop feature

recipes.title: Layered Eggplant
recipes.description: Fried eggplant slices layered with ricotta cheese mixture and topped with fresh tomato sauce.

instructions.text: Heat oven to 400°F (200°C).
Cut eggplant crosswise into 18 slices. Pat dry with paper toweling.
Mix together flour, salt and ¼ tsp pepper in shallow dish or onto waxed paper.
Heat ¼ cup oil in each of 2 large skillets over medium-high heat.
Dredge each eggplant slice in flour to coat both sides.
Fry 2 or 3 slices of eggplant per skillet until browned on both sides, about 4 minutes total. Transfer to paper toweling to drain. Repeat until all slices are fried, adding more oil as needed.
Mix cottage cheese or ricotta, Cheddar cheese, parsley, marjoram and remaining pepper in a bowl.

To assemble stacks: In large baking dish, place 1 slice eggplant. Spread on 3 tablespoons cottage cheese mixture; top with eggplant slice, 3 more tablespoons cottage cheese mixture and final slice of eggplant to make 6 stacks. Sprinkle with crumbs.
Bake, uncovered, in 400°F oven for 10 minutes.
Serve immediately with Fresh Tomato Sauce.

Fresh Tomato Sauce: Mix together in bowl 1 large tomato (seeded and diced), 3 tablespoons sliced fresh basil, 3 tablespoons balsamic vinegar, 3 tablespoons olive oil, ¼ tsp salt, and ⅛ tsp freshly ground black pepper. Makes about 1½ cups sauce.

notes: Fresh tomato sauce adds bright flavor

recipes.title: Karen Eatherly's Fruit and Cream Pie
recipes.source_note: magazine clipping (FC Good Food - Blue Ribbon Pies)
recipes.description: Graham cracker crust pie with cream cheese filling, whipped topping, and peach gelatin layer.

ingredients.item: fresh peach slices OR canned cling peaches

instructions.text: Heat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Crust: Place graham crackers in plastic bag and seal. Using rolling pin, crush into fine crumbs; you should have about 1¼ cups crumbs.
Combine crumbs and sugar in bowl. Stir in melted butter.
Press over bottom and up sides of 9-inch pie pan.
Bake in 375°F oven for 6 to 9 minutes or until edges are brown. Cool on wire rack.
Filling: Beat together cream cheese and sugar in medium-size bowl until well mixed. Stir in whipped topping.
Spread mixture evenly into crust; refrigerate.
Stir together gelatin, pudding mix and water in medium-size saucepan.
Place over medium-low heat; stir constantly just until mixture comes to a boil.
Let cool 5 minutes.
Arrange fruit in attractive pattern over top of pie.
Spoon gelatin mixture over pie. Refrigerate 4 hours or until set.

notes: From FC Good Food Blue Ribbon Pies feature

conversions.conversion_notes: Flag corrected: no metric conversions available

recipes.title: Carol Thomas's Pecan Pie
recipes.source_note: magazine clipping (FC Good Food - Blue Ribbon Pies)
recipes.description: Classic Southern pecan pie with butterscotch chips.

instructions.text: Heat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Unfold piecrust; fit into 9-inch pie pan.
Scatter butterscotch chips and pecan pieces in pie shell.
Beat together butter, sugar, corn syrup and eggs in medium-size bowl.
Pour over nuts and butterscotch chips.
Bake in 350°F oven for 45 to 50 minutes or until golden brown.
If pie browns too quickly, cover with aluminum foil after 20 minutes.
Cool pie completely on wire rack.

notes: Butterscotch chips add extra flavor dimension
Cover with foil if browning too fast

recipes.title: Jo Beard's Chess Pie
recipes.source_note: magazine clipping (FC Good Food - Blue Ribbon Pies)
recipes.description: Classic Southern chess pie with cornmeal - a simple, custardy filling.

instructions.text: Heat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Unfold piecrust; fit into 9-inch pie pan.
Mix sugar and cornmeal in bowl.
Stir in butter, eggs, vinegar, salt and vanilla.
Pour into pie shell.
Bake in 350°F oven 45 minutes or until set.
If top starts to brown, lightly cover with foil about halfway through baking.
Cool pie completely on wire rack.

notes: Classic Southern dessert
Cornmeal gives it the traditional texture

recipes.title: Cathrine Brown's Cherry Pie
recipes.source_note: magazine clipping (Family Circle, 9/1/98 - Blue Ribbon Pies)
recipes.description: Double-crust tart cherry pie with cinnamon.

instructions.text: Heat oven to 425°F (220°C). Drain cherries, reserving 1 cup juice.
Mix ¼ cup sugar, cornstarch and cinnamon in saucepan.
Stir in cherry juice. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, 5 minutes, until smooth and thickened.
Remove from heat. Stir in cherries, remaining sugar, butter, and food coloring if desired.
Unfold 1 crust; fit into 9-inch pie pan. Pour in cherry mixture.
Unfold second crust; cover pie, in lattice pattern if desired. Crimp edges.
Bake in 425°F oven 45 minutes, until golden brown and bubbly.
If pie browns too quickly, cover edges with foil. Cool on wire rack.

notes: Food coloring is optional - enhances color

recipes.title: Kay McCrary's Fried Pies
recipes.source_note: magazine clipping (FC Good Food - Blue Ribbon Pies)
recipes.description: Old-fashioned fried hand pies with apricot filling.

instructions.text: Simmer apricots, peach and water in saucepan, uncovered, 12 to 15 minutes, until soft.
Put fruit with liquid and sugar in blender. Whirl until there are no lumps.
Mix flour and salt in large bowl. With pastry blender or 2 knives held like scissors, cut in shortening until mixture resembles coarse meal.
Add milk and blend in with fork until mixture comes together in a ball; add the extra milk if needed.
Roll dough out on lightly floured surface to ¼-inch thickness.
Use 3-inch round cookie cutter to cut out circles. Gather scraps together, roll out and cut into more circles.
Place about 2 teaspoons apricot mixture in center of each circle. Fold into half-moons; crimp edges.
Fry pies, no more than 5 at a time, in 375°F oil for 3 to 5 minutes or until golden.
Drain on paper towel-lined pan.

notes: Traditional Southern fried hand pies
Can use other dried fruits

recipes.title: Sheila Farris's Chocolate Pie
recipes.source_note: magazine clipping (FC Good Food - Blue Ribbon Pies)
recipes.description: Chocolate cream pie with meringue topping.

instructions.text: Unfold piecrust; fit into 9-inch pie pan. Prebake according to package directions. Remove from oven. Reduce temperature to 350°F (175°C).
Mix 1½ cups sugar, the flour and cocoa in medium-size heavy-bottomed saucepan. Stir in just enough milk to make paste; stir in remaining milk.
Cook over medium heat, stirring, 10 to 12 minutes or until thickened. Remove from heat.
Beat yolks in medium-size bowl until thick and yellow. Carefully whisk a little of hot cocoa mixture into yolks; whisk yolk mixture back into cocoa mixture.
Bring to boiling; remove from heat. Stir in vanilla and butter just until butter is melted. Pour into pie shell.
Beat egg whites in bowl just until frothy. Add cream of tartar and beat until peaks form.
Beat in the 6 tablespoons sugar, 2 tablespoons at a time, until stiff peaks form.
Spread meringue over pie filling so it touches all around the edge, sealing the top.
Bake in 350°F oven for 12 to 15 minutes or until meringue is lightly browned.
Transfer to wire rack to cool completely.

notes: Meringue must seal edges to prevent weeping

recipes.title: Corn Stew
recipes.source_note: magazine clipping (FC Good Food - Pick of the Crop)
recipes.description: Creamy fresh corn stew with peppers and cheddar cheese.

ingredients.prep_note: shucked, kernels cut off cob (about 6 cups)

instructions.text: Melt butter in medium-size saucepan over medium-high heat.
Add onion; cook, stirring, until golden and glazed, about 5 minutes.
Add green and red peppers; cook, stirring, for 2 to 3 minutes.
Add corn kernels.
Increase heat; cook, stirring, 2 minutes.
Add light cream, parsley, salt and pepper. Cover and simmer 45 minutes.
Stir in 1 cup of Cheddar cheese and hot-pepper sauce until cheese has melted.
Ladle into bowls. Sprinkle with remaining ¼ cup shredded cheese. Serve warm.

notes: Best with fresh corn in season

recipes.title: Beet Summer Salad
recipes.description: Warm beet and cucumber salad with honey-herb dressing and hard-cooked eggs.

instructions.text: Bring 2 quarts of water in saucepan to boiling. Add ½ tsp salt and 1 tbsp lemon juice.
Add beets; cover and simmer 15 to 20 minutes. Drain; reserve broth for beet soup if desired.
Meanwhile, combine remaining salt and lemon juice, the honey and wine vinegar in large bowl; remove half of the mixture and reserve for dressing for greens.
Cut cucumbers into slices. Add to honey mixture in bowl; let stand to marinate.
When beets are cool enough to handle but still warm, remove skins. Slice in half; cut crosswise into ¼-inch-thick slices; place in bowl. Set aside, covered.
Remove cucumbers with slotted spoon from marinade and place in small saucepan. Add chicken broth; gently cook until liquid evaporates, 3 to 4 minutes. Remove from heat.
Mix beets, parsley, dill and thyme in bowl.
Whisk oil into reserved honey mixture along with any marinade left over from cucumbers. Add greens; toss to coat.
Divide greens equally among 6 plates. Arrange beets, cucumbers and egg wedges on plates.
Serve warm or at room temperature with sour cream.

notes: Save beet cooking liquid for soup

conversions.conversion_notes: Flag corrected: no metric conversions available

recipes.title: Garlicky Broccoli Rabe
recipes.description: Fettuccine with broccoli rabe in a creamy garlic sauce with two cheeses.

instructions.text: Bring large pot of salted water to boiling.
Simmer garlic, cream, broth and pepper flakes in small saucepan 20 minutes, until garlic is softened. Mash garlic into cream to blend.
Add pasta to boiling water; cook following package directions.
Heat oil in large skillet. Add broccoli rabe; sauté 3 minutes.
Add ¼ cup water; cook until water evaporates, about 5 minutes. Add salt and pepper. Remove from heat.
Drain pasta; return to pot.
Add rabe; spoon garlic mixture over top.
Sprinkle with Parmesan and Fontina cheeses; toss to mix.

notes: Note: Broccoli can be used in place of broccoli rabe. Cut flowerets from 2 pounds broccoli; cut stem in 1-inch pieces. Add to pasta in pot during last 5 minutes of cooking.

recipes.title: Rachel Gregory's Apple Pie
recipes.source_note: magazine clipping (FC Good Food - Blue Ribbon Pies)
recipes.description: Classic lattice-top apple pie with orange juice and apple pie spice.

instructions.text: Heat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Unfold 1 crust; fit into 9-inch pie pan.
Mix sugar and flour in bowl.
Cook apples and juice in saucepan for 5 to 6 minutes, until apples are tender.
Pour into pie. Sprinkle with sugar mixture. Dot with butter.
Unfold second crust; make lattice top. Sprinkle with pie spice.
Bake in 375°F oven 45 minutes or until golden brown and bubbly.
Cool on wire rack.

notes: Orange juice adds a subtle citrus flavor

recipes.title: Sammie Major's Fudge Pie
recipes.source_note: magazine clipping (FC Good Food - Blue Ribbon Pies)
recipes.description: Rich chocolate fudge pie in a prebaked shell.

instructions.text: Unfold piecrust; fit into 9-inch pie pan. Prebake crust according to package directions. Remove from oven.
Lower the oven temperature to 325°F (165°C).
Beat together sugar, flour, cocoa powder, butter, eggs and vanilla in medium-size bowl.
Spoon into pie shell.
Bake in 325°F oven 25 to 30 minutes or until set.
Transfer to wire rack to cool completely.

notes: Simple but intensely chocolatey

recipes.title: Julia's Pastry
recipes.description: Sour cream pastry crust recipe.

instructions.text: Cut butter into flour until mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Mix in sour cream and water until dough comes together.
Chill before rolling out.

notes: Also contains prep notes: chop garlic saute slowly, dice tomatoes, dice chicken, chop basil, cook pasta

flags: Handwriting difficult to read
Some quantities unclear
Instructions inferred

recipes.title: Squash Casserole
recipes.description: Southern squash casserole topped with crumbled cornbread.

instructions.text: Sauté onions in butter until soft.
Add cut up squash and cook until tender (reserve cooking liquid).
Add package of cheese to the hot squash mixture.
Crumble baked cornbread over the mixture.
Add some cooking liquid to moisten.
Transfer to casserole dish.
Bake covered for 1 hour, uncovering the last 30 minutes to brown the top.

notes: Traditional Southern side dish
Temperature inferred - standard casserole temp
Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 612.jpeg

flags: Temperature inferred
Some quantities unclear from handwriting

recipes.title: Sangria
recipes.description: Homemade Spanish-style sangria with orange liqueur and brandy.

instructions.text: Combine liqueur, brandy and sugar.
When sugar has dissolved, add wine and club soda.
If desired, add slices of fruit.
Store in refrigerator in tightly closed bottle.

notes: Donna advises: buy a large bottle of wine for better price per ounce
Add fresh bottle of club soda each time you serve, as it goes flat after opening

conversions.conversion_notes: Flag corrected: no metric conversions available

recipes.title: Hooters Buffalo Chicken Wings
recipes.description: Nearly world famous. Often imitated, hardly ever duplicated. Copycat recipe for Hooters-style buffalo wings.

ingredients.item: Crystal Louisiana Hot Sauce or Frank's Red Hot Cayenne Sauce

instructions.text: Heat oil in a deep fryer to 375°F. You want just enough oil to cover the wings entirely—an inch or so deep at least.
Combine the butter, hot sauce, ground pepper, and garlic powder in a small saucepan over low heat. Heat until the butter is melted and the ingredients are well-blended.
Combine the flour, paprika, cayenne pepper, and salt in a small bowl.
If the wings are frozen, be sure to defrost and dry them. Put the wings into a large bowl and sprinkle the flour mixture over them, coating each wing evenly.
Put the wings in the refrigerator for 60 to 90 minutes. (This will help the breading to stick to the wings when fried.)
Put all the wings into the hot oil and fry them for 10 to 15 minutes or until some parts of the wings begin to turn dark brown.
Remove the wings from the oil to a paper towel to drain. But don't let them sit too long, because you want to serve the wings hot.

Quickly put the wings into a large bowl. Add the hot sauce and stir, coating all of the wings evenly. You could also use a large plastic container (such as Tupperware) with a lid for this. Put all the wings inside the container, add the sauce, put on the lid, then shake.
Serve with bleu cheese dressing and celery sticks on the side.

notes: From Top Secret Recipes cookbook
Hooters started in Clearwater, Florida on April Fool's Day 1983
The refrigeration step is key for crispy coating

recipes.title: Carrot Raisin Muffins
recipes.description: Wholesome muffins with carrots, pineapple, and raisins.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Grease or line 12 muffin cups.
Mix dry ingredients (flours, sugar, baking powder, cinnamon, ginger) in a large bowl.
In another bowl, combine beaten eggs, crushed pineapple (with juice), grated carrot, raisins, corn syrup, and vanilla.
Add wet ingredients to dry and stir just until combined.
Fold in nuts if using.
Fill muffin cups ⅔ full.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 20 minutes or until golden and a toothpick comes out clean.

notes: The pineapple keeps these moist

recipes.title: Amaranth (Cooking Guide)
recipes.description: The sacred grain of the Aztecs, domesticated in Mexico 7,000 years ago. Can be cooked as porridge or toasted.

instructions.text: Use a ratio of 3 cups liquid to 1 cup amaranth. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 20 to 30 minutes.
If necessary, remove from heat and let sit, covered, until liquid is absorbed. Do not allow to boil over, because it is very sticky.
Do not salt until thoroughly cooked.
Alternatively, toast 1 cup of seeds in skillet or saucepan for 2 to 4 minutes or until the seeds pop.
Bring 1 cup water plus 1 tsp vegetable oil to a boil, add toasted amaranth, and simmer for 7 minutes or until liquid has been absorbed.
Remove from heat and let steam for an additional 5 to 10 minutes.
Stir in raisins, chopped dates or nuts, honey, molasses or maple syrup for breakfast cereal. Mix with corn, green onions and cooked pinto beans for an entree or side dish.

notes: Part of 'Go With The Grains For Robust Flavors' feature

recipes.title: Barley (Cooking Guide)
recipes.description: Possibly the oldest grain on the planet, barley can grow in virtually any climate.

instructions.text: Combine 3½ to 4 cups stock with 1 cup barley, plus salt and butter to taste.
Bring to a boil, then simmer for 35 to 40 minutes, until liquid is absorbed and barley is tender.
Serve with butter or use as an ingredient in recipes.

notes: Part of 'Go With The Grains For Robust Flavors' feature

recipes.title: Oat Groats (Cooking Guide)
recipes.description: The whole grain with only the inedible chaff removed. Chewy texture and almost-meaty flavor.

instructions.text: Toast 1 cup oats in saucepan or skillet over medium-high heat, stirring constantly, until aromatic and slightly darker, about 4 minutes.
Boil 1¾ cups water or stock with salt and butter to taste, add the oats, simmer covered for 45 minutes until liquid absorbed.
Remove from heat and let stand covered for 10 minutes, then fluff.
Serve with butter or toasted nuts.

notes: Part of 'Go With The Grains' feature

recipes.title: Polenta (Cooking Guide)
recipes.description: A staple in many regions of Italy, made of meal ground from flint corn.

instructions.text: For every 1 cup polenta, bring 3 cups salted water to boil.
Slowly whisk in polenta, then reduce heat to medium.
Stir with wooden spoon, stirring frequently, about 30 minutes until thick and pulls from sides.
Stir in 1 tbsp olive oil, scrape into bowl, rest 7 minutes before turning out.

notes: Part of 'Go With The Grains' feature

recipes.title: Quinoa (Cooking Guide)
recipes.description: Cultivated in the Andes 8,000 years ago. Very high in protein, expands 4x when cooked.

instructions.text: Rinse several times before cooking to remove bitterness.
Bring 2 cups water to boil for every 1 cup quinoa.
Simmer for 20 minutes.
Use as stuffing for vegetables, with salsas or chutneys, or with fruits and nuts.

notes: Part of 'Go With The Grains' feature
Rinse before cooking to remove bitter coating

recipes.title: Hard Red Winter Wheat Berries (Cooking Guide)
recipes.description: Wheat is the world's most widely distributed grain, grown in virtually every country.

instructions.text: Bring 3 cups water to boil, add 1 cup wheat berries, reduce heat and simmer for 1½ hours.
Do not add salt.
Serve as side dish with butter, salt, pepper and parsley, or use for grain salad with bean sprouts, carrots and green onions.

notes: Part of 'Go With The Grains' feature

recipes.title: Kamut (Cooking Guide)
recipes.description: Ancient grain dating to 6,000 years ago in Egypt. Chewy texture and mildly nutty taste.

instructions.text: Combine 1 cup kamut with 2 cups lightly salted water.
Bring to boil, reduce heat and simmer until tender, about 50 minutes to 1 hour.
Kamut triples in volume when cooked.

notes: Part of 'Go With The Grains' feature

recipes.title: Millet (Cooking Guide)
recipes.description: Ancient grain brought to the American heartland by Russian Mennonites in the 19th century.

instructions.text: Use ratio of 3 cups liquid to 1 cup millet.
Bring to boil, cover and simmer for 20 to 25 minutes.
Remove from heat, fluff and let sit covered for 10 minutes.
Use as base for sauteed vegetables.

notes: Part of 'Go With The Grains' feature

recipes.title: Roasted Veggie Tacos
recipes.description: Vegetarian tacos with roasted peppers, tomatoes, and onions served with refried beans.

instructions.text: Place 1 oven rack in bottom rack position. Heat oven to 475°F (245°C).
Spread tomatoes, bell peppers and onions in ungreased 15-by-10-inch baking pan. Drizzle with oil; toss to coat.
Sprinkle with taco seasoning; toss to evenly coat.
Bake at 475°F on bottom oven rack for 15 minutes or until bell peppers and onions are crisp-tender.
Meanwhile, spread 2 tbsp refried beans on half of inside of each taco shell. Arrange taco shells on ungreased cookie sheet.
Place tacos on middle oven rack with vegetables. Bake 1 to 2 minutes more until tacos are warmed.
To serve, spoon about ⅓ cup vegetable mixture over refried bean in each shell. Serve with salsa.

conversions.conversion_notes: Flag corrected: no metric conversions available

recipes.title: Butterscotch Schnapps Cookies
recipes.attribution: Carol Drake, St. Clair Shores, MI
recipes.description: Soft cookies made with yellow cake mix and butterscotch chips, finished with butterscotch schnapps drizzle.

instructions.text: Heat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease cookie sheets.
Cream butter and cream cheese. Blend in egg and vanilla.
Mix in cake mix by hand. Mix in butterscotch chips.
Drop by teaspoon on cookie sheet.
Bake 8-10 minutes. Remove from oven and let cool on cookie sheet.
Lace each cookie with Butterscotch Schnapps, a couple of drops, using a teaspoon.

notes: You may substitute chocolate chips and Peppermint Schnapps for a variation

recipes.title: Ring in the New Year Soup
recipes.description: Traditional Southern black-eye pea soup for New Year's Day good luck, with sausage and rice.

instructions.text: Combine black-eye peas, water, tomatoes, rice and salt in crockpot or soup pot.
Brown sausage, onion and bell pepper, drain and add to black-eye pea mixture.
Simmer for 30 minutes.
When ready to serve, top with sour cream and shredded cheddar cheese.

notes: Southern New Year's tradition - black-eye peas bring good luck!
Can be made in crockpot or on stovetop

conversions.conversion_notes: Flag corrected: no metric conversions available

recipes.title: Coconut Delights
recipes.description: No-bake coconut date balls rolled in graham cracker crumbs.

instructions.text: Mix all ingredients together.
Chill mixture for ½ hour.
Shape into balls and roll in graham crackers.

notes: No-bake recipe

conversions.conversion_notes: Flag corrected: no metric conversions available

recipes.title: Grandma's Peanut Butter Cookies
recipes.description: Classic peanut butter cookies with the signature criss-cross fork pattern.

instructions.text: In a mixing bowl, cream shortening, peanut butter and sugars.
Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition.
Combine flour, baking soda and salt; gradually add to creamed mixture.
Roll into 1-1/2-inch balls and place 3 inches apart on ungreased baking sheets.
Flatten with a fork, pressing once in each direction to make criss-cross pattern.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 10-15 minutes or until bottoms are lightly browned.
Remove to wire racks to cool.

notes: Use shiny aluminum baking sheets without sides for golden brown cookies
Preheat oven 10-15 minutes before baking

recipes.title: Virginia's Pickled Veggies
recipes.description: Quick pickling brine for mixed vegetables - cucumbers, beans, squash, carrots.

instructions.text: Combine sugar, white vinegar, water, salt and dill in a pot.
Boil for 1 minute.
Pour over veggies - unpeeled cucumbers, beans, sliced squash, carrots, etc.
Add clove of garlic to each jar.

notes: Amount of sugar can be reduced to 1½ cups

recipes.title: Pickled Beans (Dilly Beans)
recipes.description: Classic dilly beans for canning - crisp pickled green beans with garlic and dill.

ingredients.prep_note: chopped, or sprig fresh dill per jar

instructions.text: Snip beans and parboil unsalted for 10 minutes. Cool in ice water.
Place clove garlic in each jar. Add 2 tbsp chopped dill, or sprig of fresh dill.
Heat 2 cups water, 2 cups white vinegar, 4 tsp sugar, and 4 tbsp salt.
Bring to boil and pour over beans in jar to full. Seal.

notes: Parboiling and ice bath keeps beans crisp
For proper canning, follow current USDA guidelines
