recipes.title: Oatmeal Cookies
recipes.description: Classic oatmeal cookies with raisins and nuts.

instructions.text: Cream sugar and oleo together.
Add eggs and mix well.
Combine flour, oatmeal, baking soda, baking powder, and cinnamon.
Add dry ingredients alternately with milk.
Stir in raisins and nuts.
Drop by spoonfuls onto greased cookie sheet.
Bake until golden brown.

notes: Oleo is margarine - can substitute butter

flags: handwriting interpretation
baking temp/time not specified

recipes.title: Old Fashioned Spare Ribs
recipes.description: Tender spare ribs slow-cooked in a tangy tomato-based sauce.

instructions.text: Put ribs in roaster.
Stir up the sauce: combine catsup, vinegar, Worcestershire sauce, salt, pepper, chili powder, water, and chopped onion.
Pour sauce over meat.
Cook covered about 2 hours at 350°F (175°C).
Uncover for 30 minutes.
Turn and baste several times during cooking.

notes: Baste several times for best results

recipes.title: Rhubarb Pie (Handwritten)
recipes.description: Classic rhubarb pie with egg-enriched filling.

instructions.text: Mix rhubarb, flour, sugar, beaten egg, and salt together.
Pour into unbaked pie crust.
Dot with butter.
Add top crust if desired.
Bake at 450°F (230°C) for 45 minutes.

notes: High temperature - watch carefully

recipes.title: Lois' Ice Box Pickles
recipes.description: Refrigerator pickles with turmeric and pickling spices - no canning required.

instructions.text: Heat sugar and vinegar to dissolve the sugar.
Add salt, turmeric, celery seed, and mustard seed.
Pour over prepared cucumbers in jars.
Refrigerate - no canning needed.

notes: Ice box pickles store in refrigerator, not shelf-stable

recipes.title: Bread & Butter Pickles
recipes.description: Classic sweet bread and butter pickles with pickling spices.

instructions.text: Slice cucumbers and onions, layer with salt, let sit, then drain.
Heat vinegar and sugar with mustard seed, celery seed, and turmeric.
Add drained cucumbers and onions.
Pack into jars and process according to canning guidelines.

notes: Classic sweet pickle recipe
Follow USDA canning guidelines for safe processing

recipes.title: Janet's Pie
recipes.description: No-bake peanut butter cream cheese pie with Cool Whip topping.

instructions.text: Beat cream cheese, sugar, and peanut butter together until smooth.
Add 8 oz (or ½ container) of Cool Whip and mix well.
Pour into prepared pie crust.
Spread remaining Cool Whip on top.
Refrigerate until set.

notes: No-bake recipe
Can use sugar substitute for diabetic-friendly version

recipes.title: Erdine's Rice Crispies
recipes.description: Peanut butter Rice Krispies treats topped with chocolate and butterscotch chips.

instructions.text: Heat sugar and corn syrup to boiling.
Add peanut butter and mix together well.
Add Rice Krispies and stir to coat.
Press into 9x13 pan.
Top with ½ package chocolate chips and ½ package butterscotch chips while still warm.
Let chips melt, then spread evenly. Let cool and cut into bars.

notes: No-bake recipe
Spread chips while treats are warm to melt

recipes.title: Corn Pudding
recipes.description: Fresh corn pudding with ham, eggs, and Parmesan cheese.

instructions.text: Cut corn off 4 ears of corn.
Saute corn in olive oil. Add onions, ham, salt and pepper.
Whisk 6 eggs with 1 cup milk.
Add egg mixture to corn mixture.
Add nutmeg and Parmesan cheese.
Pour into baking dish and bake at 325°F (165°C) for 45 minutes to 1 hour until set.

notes: Great way to use fresh summer corn

flags: some ingredient amounts not specified

recipes.title: Oven Potatoes
recipes.description: Crispy oven-baked potato wedges coated in flour and Parmesan cheese.

instructions.text: Mix flour and Parmesan cheese together.
Cut potatoes into wedges and coat in flour-cheese mixture.
Place on cookie sheet.
Drizzle melted oleo (or butter) over top.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) until done, about 45 minutes.

notes: Simple and delicious side dish

recipes.title: Baked Chicken (Pepsi Can)
recipes.description: Beer-can style chicken using Pepsi for moist, flavorful roasted chicken.

instructions.text: Open a can of Pepsi and pour out (or drink) half.
Add lemon juice and Worcestershire sauce to the can.
Set chicken over the can so it stands upright.
Bake until chicken is cooked through and golden.

notes: Similar to beer can chicken - the soda keeps the chicken moist

flags: bake time not specified

recipes.title: Texas Squealer
recipes.description: Quick sausage and pepper wrap with hot salsa.

instructions.text: Cook sausage with onion and pepper.
Place mixture on tortilla shell.
Add hot salsa.
Roll up and eat!

notes: Quick and easy meal

recipes.title: Orange Chocolate Biscotti with Almonds
recipes.description: Chocolate biscotti made easy with cake mix, flavored with orange zest and studded with almonds.

instructions.text: Mix cake mix, melted butter, eggs, flour, almonds, and orange zest in large mixing bowl.
Blend with mixer until well mixed - dough will be thick and form a large ball.
Pat ball on greased cookie sheet. Flour hands and shape into a log about 14x4x½ inches, a little higher in center.
Bake biscotti until toothpick comes out clean, 30-35 minutes.
Remove from oven (leave oven on) and let cool for 10 minutes.
Cutting on baking sheet with serrated knife, slice into ¾-inch slices.
Lay slices on their side on baking sheet.
Return to oven and bake 10 minutes.
Turn oven off and leave biscotti in oven for 30 minutes.
Cool 2 hours. Store in airtight container.

notes: Uses cake mix for easy preparation
Perfect for dipping in coffee

recipes.title: Tempura Batter (for Chicken)
recipes.description: Light, crispy tempura batter for fried chicken.

instructions.text: Mix flour, club soda, egg, and buttermilk to form batter.
Dip chicken pieces in batter.
Fry to golden brown.
Put in oven to finish cooking if needed.

notes: Club soda makes the batter extra light and crispy

recipes.title: Pickled Beans (Variant)
recipes.description: Another version of dilly beans for canning.

instructions.text: Snip beans and parboil for 10 minutes.
Cool in ice water.
Put ½ clove garlic in each jar.
Add 2 tbsp chopped dill or sprig to each jar.
Heat water, vinegar, sugar, and salt - bring to boil.
Pour over beans and seal.

recipes.title: Pickled Veggies (Variant)
recipes.description: Simple pickling brine for vegetables.

instructions.text: Combine sugar, water, vinegar, and salt.
Boil for 1 minute.
Pour over prepared vegetables.

notes: Sugar amount can be adjusted to taste

recipes.title: Blueberry Muffins
recipes.description: Classic homemade blueberry muffins.

instructions.text: Mix flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt together (dry ingredients).
In separate bowl, mix egg, oil, and milk.
Pour wet ingredients over dry ingredients.
Fold in blueberries.
Fill muffin cups about ⅔ full.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 25 minutes.

recipes.variant_notes: Files 660 and 1080 show same recipe with slight variation: 1/3 cup oil (vs 1/2 cup), 1 cup blueberries (vs 1.25 cups)

recipes.title: Heath Bars (Saltine Toffee)
recipes.description: Addictive saltine cracker toffee topped with chocolate - also known as Christmas Crack!

instructions.text: Line cookie sheet with foil.
Lay crackers in single layer on foil.
Melt butter and brown sugar over medium heat.
Bring to boil for 3 minutes, stirring constantly!
Cool 2 minutes, then pour over crackers.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 5 minutes.
Pour chocolate chips on top and smooth over as chocolate melts.
Sprinkle with chopped nuts if desired.
Let cool completely, then break into pieces.

notes: Also called Christmas Crack or Cracker Candy
Marked 'good' in original recipe!

recipes.title: Janet's Salad (Ramen Noodle Salad)
recipes.description: Crunchy Asian-style cabbage salad with toasted ramen noodles and almonds.

instructions.text: Chop cabbage and onion.
Brown broken ramen noodles and almonds in a pan. Add sesame seeds.
Make dressing: combine sugar, vinegar, soy sauce, and seasoning packet from ramen noodles.
Toss cabbage and onion with dressing.
Top with toasted noodles, almonds, and sesame seeds just before serving.

notes: Add crunchy toppings just before serving to maintain crunch

recipes.title: Lena's Cream Pie
recipes.description: Simple no-bake cream cheese pie with optional berries.

instructions.text: Beat cream cheese and sugar together until smooth.
Fold in Cool Whip.
Pour into graham cracker crust.
Refrigerate until set.
Top with fresh berries if desired.

notes: No-bake recipe
Great with strawberries or blueberries

recipes.title: Fran's Dump Cake
recipes.description: Grandma Baker's easy dump cake with pineapple and fruit pie filling topped with yellow cake mix.

instructions.text: Spread chopped pecans on bottom of 9x13 pan.
Spread crushed pineapple over pecans.
Spread fruit pie filling over pineapple.
Sprinkle dry yellow cake mix evenly over top.
Drizzle melted butter over cake mix.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) until golden and bubbly.

notes: Called 'dump cake' because you just dump in the ingredients
No mixing required!

recipes.title: Broccoli Salad with Bacon and Eggs
recipes.description: Creamy broccoli salad with mashed hard-boiled eggs and crispy bacon.

instructions.text: Cut up broccoli into bite-size florets.
Add chopped onion.
Add mashed hard-boiled eggs.
Add crushed crispy bacon.
Mix dressing: mayo, vinegar (or lemon juice), a little sugar, salt and pepper.
Toss salad with dressing.

notes: Best when chilled for a few hours before serving

recipes.title: Constipation Recipe (Prune-Fig Remedy)
recipes.description: Traditional home remedy with prunes, figs, raisins, and senna tea.

instructions.text: Steep 4 oz senna tea in 1 pint of boiling water for 20 minutes.
Strain the tea.
Cook prunes, figs, raisins, lemon juice, and brown sugar with the strained tea for 5 minutes.
Store in refrigerator or freezer.
Take 2 tablespoons at breakfast.

notes: Can be frozen
Can make ½ batch
Traditional home remedy - consult doctor before use

recipes.title: Ethel's Pie Crust
recipes.description: Reliable pie crust recipe using Crisco, makes multiple crusts.

ingredients.prep_note: enough to make 1 cup with egg

instructions.text: Mix flour, salt, and baking powder.
Cut in Crisco until mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Beat egg in a 1-cup measure, add water to make 1 cup total.
Add vinegar to egg mixture.
Add wet ingredients to flour mixture and mix until dough forms.
Divide into portions and roll out as needed.

notes: Use 4 cups flour if using lard instead of Crisco
Vinegar makes crust tender

recipes.title: Raisin Scones
recipes.description: Classic British-style raisin scones with nutrition information.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).
Whisk milk and egg together.
Mix dry ingredients in another bowl.
Drop the butter into the flour and using your fingers, rub until the mixture is pebbly.
Pour in milk and egg mixture. Mix with a fork until dough is evenly moist.
Add raisins and stir.
Spoon a dozen mounds of dough onto baking sheet.
Bake for 20-22 minutes until golden.

recipes.title: Rhubarb Cake (with Jello and Marshmallows)
recipes.description: Rhubarb dessert layered with Jello and marshmallows, topped with yellow cake.

instructions.text: Put chopped rhubarb in 9x14 inch pan.
Sprinkle sugar over rhubarb.
Sprinkle dry Jello powder over sugar.
Layer mini marshmallows on top.
Prepare yellow cake mix according to package directions.
Pour prepared cake batter on top of marshmallows.
Bake at 325°F (165°C) for about 1 hour.

notes: The marshmallows create a gooey layer
Rhubarb sinks to bottom during baking

recipes.title: Dump Cake - Jean B
recipes.description: Easy dump cake with pineapple, cherry pie filling, and coconut topped with cake mix and butter.

instructions.text: Lightly grease a 9x13 inch pan.
Dump in crushed pineapple and spread evenly.
Spoon cherry pie filling over the pineapple.
Dump in flaked coconut as evenly as you can.
Dump box of yellow cake mix over all.
Pour melted butter over top of cake.
Sprinkle top with chopped nuts.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) until brown on top, about 45 minutes.

notes: Great eaten warm or with Cool Whip
Variant technique: Mix cake mix with melted butter before spreading over fruit. Use pastry blender to mix.
recipes.variant_notes: This version adds coconut and uses butter instead of margarine

recipes.title: Peanut Butter Cookies (Flourless)
recipes.source_note: Newspaper clipping - recipe shared for Jewel Curley of Largo
recipes.description: Simple 4-ingredient flourless peanut butter cookies - naturally gluten-free.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Mix together all ingredients until well combined.
Roll into balls using about 1 teaspoon of dough for each.
Place on greased cookie sheet.
Press tops with fork to create criss-cross pattern.
Bake at 350°F for 12 minutes or until lightly browned.

notes: This is the famous 4-ingredient flourless peanut butter cookie recipe
Naturally gluten-free

recipes.title: Classic Lasagna (Johnsonville)
recipes.description: Hearty layered lasagna with Italian sausage, ricotta, and mozzarella using no-boil noodles.

ingredients.item: Barilla Italian Baking Sauce or Marinara

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Spray baking pan (13x9x3 inch deep) with nonstick cooking spray.
Remove 16 lasagna noodles from box. DO NOT BOIL.
In medium bowl, beat eggs. Stir in ricotta, 2 cups mozzarella and Parmesan.
Layer lasagna, slightly overlapping sheets. Lasagna will expand to edges during cooking. Spread fillings to edges to seal in and cook lasagna during baking.
Layer in following order: 1 cup sauce on bottom, 4 uncooked noodles, 1/3 ricotta mixture, half of browned meat, 1 cup mozzarella, 1 cup sauce.
Layer 4 uncooked noodles, 1/3 ricotta mixture, and 1.5 cups sauce.
Layer 4 uncooked noodles, remaining ricotta mixture, browned meat, and 1 cup sauce.
Layer 4 uncooked noodles and remaining sauce.
Bake covered with foil until bubbly, 50-60 minutes.
Uncover. Add remaining 1 cup mozzarella and continue cooking until cheese is melted, about 5 minutes.
Let stand 15 minutes before cutting.

notes: If using a 2-inch deep pan, make 3 layers to avoid possible boiling over. Use same amount of filling and 12 uncooked noodles.

recipes.title: Gingerbread House
recipes.source_note: The Tampa Tribune, 1996 - from 'An Edible Christmas' by Irena Chalmers (Morrow)
recipes.description: Complete gingerbread house with dough recipe and detailed assembly instructions using royal icing and candy decorations.

instructions.text: DOUGH: In a medium bowl, sift flour, cinnamon, ginger, cloves, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.
In a large bowl with electric mixer at high, beat shortening and sugar 3 minutes. Add molasses and egg; beat 3 minutes or until well blended.
Add flour mixture and stir, by hand, to form smooth dough. Divide dough in half, wrap each half in plastic, and refrigerate at least 1 hour or overnight.
Make 3 patterns for the house: one side, one end, and one roof pattern.
Heat oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly dust flour on ungreased cookie sheet or back of ungreased jelly-roll pan.
Roll one ball of dough to 1/8-inch thick. Lay out cardboard patterns and cut around each one with knife. Remove excess dough.
Run knife around each piece to clean up ragged edges. Bake 15 to 18 minutes.
Immediately run a long spatula under each piece to prevent sticking. Let cool 5 minutes on cookie sheet; transfer to wire rack; cool completely.

ICING: In a large bowl, stir confectioners' sugar and egg whites. With electric mixer, beat at high 5 minutes until mixture is stiff. Fill a zipper bag with icing, seal, and snip one corner to make a 1/4-inch hole.
TO ASSEMBLE: Decorate front end piece and two side pieces as desired, using icing as glue.

Pipe thick line of icing along bottom edge of back end piece; pipe thick line of icing on bottom and back edges of one side piece. Stand and join the back end and side on cardboard base, holding in place several minutes. Use tall glasses to support while drying.
Reinforce house with icing along inside joints. Add remaining side and front pieces the same way. Let set.
TO ADD ROOF: Pipe icing along top edges; press roof pieces into place and hold for several minutes. Let icing set completely.
FOR THATCH ROOF: Split shredded-wheat biscuits in half lengthwise. Pipe two thick rows of icing on inside of each half; press halves onto roof to create 'thatch' rows. Cover both sides.
Decorate front edge of roof with thick line of icing studded with jelly beans.
Make 'icicles' on bottom edges of roof by piping large dots of icing and pulling pastry tip downward.
Make chimney on back end of roof from jelly beans stacked like bricks.

notes: Makes 6 pieces for the house: 1 front end, 1 back end, 2 sides, 2 roof pieces
Royal icing sets hard - work quickly

recipes.title: Min's Cake
recipes.description: Simple yellow cake with vanilla - a basic homestyle recipe.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Mix oleo, sugar, and vanilla together.
Crack 2 eggs into a measuring cup and fill the rest with milk. Beat well.
Add egg-milk mixture to the oleo mixture and beat well.
Mix flour, baking powder, and salt. Add to wet ingredients.
Pour into greased pan and bake at 350°F until done.

notes: Faded/stained card - some details difficult to read
The eggs-in-cup-filled-with-milk technique was common in older recipes

flags: Card stained and faded, some measurements approximate

recipes.title: Cherry Fruitcake
recipes.description: Rich fruitcake with raisins, candied cherries, citron, and rum - makes a 5-pound cake.

instructions.text: In bowl, combine raisins, cherries, citron, and rum; with spoon, mix well.
Preheat oven to 300°F (150°C). Grease 10-inch tube pan. Line bottom and side with brown paper.
In large bowl of mixer, at medium speed, beat butter with sugar and extract until fluffy.
Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition.
At low speed, gradually beat in flour.
Add prepared raisin mixture. Turn out into prepared pan.
Bake about 2 hours and 25 minutes, or until cake tester inserted in center comes out clean.
Let cool in pan on wire rack 30 minutes. Turn out of pan; let cool completely on rack.

notes: Line pan with brown paper for easy removal
Low temperature and long baking time prevents burning

recipes.title: Evelyn J. Wilson's Fruitcake
recipes.description: A lavish fruitcake loaded with dried fruits, nuts, and soaked in rum and orange liqueur.

ingredients.prep_note: can substitute pineapple or orange juice

instructions.text: Have all ingredients at room temperature. Mix first seven ingredients (fruits and nuts) in a large bowl; add 1 cup of the flour and mix with wooden spoon to coat mixture.
Sift remaining 2 cups of flour once, then add mace, salt and spices. Sift again.
Cream butter in electric mixer; add both sugars gradually, creaming well.
Stir in the 4 beaten eggs and beat until smooth and fluffy; stir in molasses and extracts.
Add remaining flour gradually and alternately with sherry and grape juice.
Pour batter into fruit and nut mixture. Mix with hands or wooden spoon, lifting fruit and nuts through mixture until well distributed.
Take the egg whites and mix well with wooden spoon through mixture.
Place in foil loaf pans (3 to 4 pans). Do not fill to top.
Bake at 350°F (175°C), 2 to 2½ hours, or until cakes test done.
Cool cakes in pan; remove and seal with foil or plastic wrap. Store in sealed containers.
Open seal and add rum; seal. A few days later, open seal and add orange liqueur.

notes: Age cake with rum and orange liqueur for best flavor
Non-alcoholic version: use extra fruit juice instead of sherry

recipes.title: Rice Krispie Dessert
recipes.description: Frozen dessert with a crispy Rice Krispie crust layered with ice cream.

instructions.text: Combine Rice Krispies, melted butter, coconut, chopped nuts, and brown sugar.
Spread half of mixture in an 8-inch pan.
Cover with 1 pint ice cream.
Spread on remaining mixture.
Return to freezer until ready to serve.
Remove a few minutes before ready to serve. Cut and serve.

notes: Use any flavor ice cream you prefer

recipes.title: Bacon Bites
recipes.description: Sweet and savory candied bacon bites cooked in the microwave - addictive party appetizer.

instructions.text: Arrange bacon slices, about 6 at a time, in a single layer on a microwave roasting rack set in a glass baking dish.
Combine brown sugar and mustard.
Sprinkle evenly over bacon.
Cook on high 1 minute per bacon slice.
Drain on paper towels.
Break into bite-sized pieces when cool.

recipes.pan_size: Microwave roasting rack in glass dish
notes: Also known as 'Millionaire Bacon' or 'Pig Candy'
Can also be baked in oven at 400°F

recipes.title: Oatmeal Cake
recipes.description: Moist oatmeal cake with brown sugar and cinnamon.

instructions.text: In a medium bowl, pour water on oats, set aside and let stand 20 minutes.
In a large bowl, cream shortening, sugars, eggs, salt, and cinnamon.
Add oat mixture, stir well.
Add flour and soda, mix again.
Pour into a greased 9-by-13-inch pan.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 30-40 minutes.
A few minutes before cake is done, make topping.

notes: Original recipe mentions 'Cake Topping (below)' but topping recipe was cut off
Typically topped with broiled coconut-pecan frosting

flags: Topping recipe cut off from clipping

recipes.title: Graham Cracker Village
recipes.description: Holiday craft project - miniature houses and churches made from milk cartons and graham crackers decorated with frosting.
recipes.servings_yield: 4 houses or 1 church and 1 tree (per can of frosting)

ingredients.prep_note: 2½-by-2½-inch squares, 8 for each house, 18 for each church

instructions.text: Cut upright center seal from milk carton; securely tape center together to form roof.
Completely cover 2 sides of carton with ¼-inch thick layer of frosting.
Firmly press 1 graham cracker square on each frosted side of carton. Repeat for remaining sides.
Fill in front and back peaks with frosting. If desired, cut crackers to fit peaks; press in place.
Cover roof portion with ¼-inch layer of frosting.
Cut 3 crackers in half, forming 6 rectangles. Arrange 3 halves vertically on each side of roof; press in place. (There will be some overhang.)
Allow frosting to set about 10 minutes.
Place frosting in decorating bag with star or open tip. Decorate houses with frosting and candies, using frosting to secure candies.
Repeat to make each house.

notes: If 8-ounce milk cartons are not available, quart cartons can be used - cut 5 inches off bottom of each carton
One can of frosting will frost 4 houses or 1 church and 1 tree
Great holiday project for kids

recipes.title: Easy Pesto Pinwheels
recipes.description: Quick and easy appetizers made with crescent rolls, pesto, and roasted red peppers.

instructions.text: Heat oven to 350°F (175°C).
Unroll dough into two long rectangles. Firmly press perforations to smooth.
Spread rectangles with pesto to within ¼-inch of edges; sprinkle with bell peppers.
Starting at shortest side, roll up each rectangle; pinch edges to seal.
Cut each roll into eight slices.
Place, cut side down, on ungreased cookie sheet.
Bake at 350°F for 13 to 17 minutes or until golden brown.
Immediately remove from cookie sheet. Serve warm.

notes: Can substitute sun-dried tomatoes for roasted peppers
Make ahead and refrigerate before baking

recipes.title: White Chocolate Snack Mix
recipes.description: Sweet and salty snack mix coated in white chocolate.

instructions.text: [UNCLEAR - instructions not visible on card. Likely: Melt white chocolate and coat cereal mixture, then spread to cool.]

notes: Instructions not visible on card - typical method is to melt white chocolate, mix with dry ingredients, spread on waxed paper to set

flags: Instructions not visible on original card

recipes.title: No-Stir Polenta
recipes.description: Easy oven-baked polenta that requires no stirring - adjust water for desired consistency.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a heavy, ovenproof, 12-inch saucepan.
Add polenta, water, butter and salt to pan. Stir with a fork until blended. (It will separate and won't come together until more than half of the cooking time has elapsed.)
Bake, uncovered, for 1 hour and 20 minutes.
Stir the polenta with a long-pronged fork, add salt to taste, and bake 10 minutes longer.
Remove from the oven; let rest for 5 minutes before pouring into a buttered bowl.
Serve simply with butter or Parmesan cheese; serve as a side dish as a collector for the main course's sauces; or use as a base for other recipes.

notes: Water consistency guide: Very soft polenta = 12 cups water; Soft = 10 cups; Medium = 8 cups; Very firm = 6 cups

recipes.title: Basic Fat-Burning Soup
recipes.description: Low-calorie vegetable soup popular in the cabbage soup diet.

instructions.text: Cut vegetables in small pieces and cover with water.
Season with salt and pepper, parsley and, if desired, curry, bouillon or hot sauce.
Boil 10 minutes.
Add onion soup mix; reduce to simmer and continue cooking until vegetables are tender.

notes: Popular 1990s diet soup
Can add other low-calorie vegetables as desired

recipes.title: Polenta Dumplings with Mushrooms and Taleggio
recipes.description: Baked polenta cubes topped with sautéed oyster mushrooms, Taleggio cheese, and browned butter.

ingredients.prep_note: cut into 1-inch cubes (leftover or prepackaged may be used)
brushed and cut into fine strips

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a small, shallow baking dish.
Drop polenta into salted boiling water; cook for 5 minutes. Drain and set aside.
Heat olive oil in an 8-inch skillet over medium heat; fry garlic until golden brown. Discard garlic.
Add mushrooms and a pinch of salt; cook, stirring, for 3 minutes. If the mushrooms are dry, add a few tablespoons of water to the skillet.
Add parsley and pepper, cover and reduce heat. Cook for 15 minutes.
Spread mushrooms across the bottom of prepared baking dish. Cover with polenta in an even layer. Top with cheese.
Bake until heated through, about 20 minutes.
Remove from oven and allow to rest 5 minutes.
Melt butter in a small pan. Heat to sizzling, then pour over the polenta and mushrooms.

notes: Taleggio is a semi-soft Italian cheese - can substitute fontina or brie if unavailable

recipes.title: Sauerkraut Surprise Cake
recipes.description: Moist chocolate cake with a secret ingredient - sauerkraut! Topped with sour cream-chocolate frosting.

instructions.text: In a large mixing bowl, cream butter and sugar until light.
Beat in eggs, one at a time, add vanilla.
Sift together flour, baking powder, soda, salt and cocoa powder.
Add dry ingredients to creamed mixture alternately with water, beating after each addition.
Stir in sauerkraut.
Turn into greased and floured 9-by-13-inch pan.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 35 to 40 minutes.
Cool in pan. Frost when cool.

notes: The sauerkraut adds moisture and texture - no one will guess the secret ingredient!
Includes Sour Cream-Chocolate Frosting recipe

frosting_recipe.title: Sour Cream-Chocolate Frosting
frosting_recipe.instructions: Melt chocolate chips and butter over low heat. Remove from heat; blend in sour cream, vanilla and salt. Gradually add powdered sugar to make spreading consistency, beat well.

recipes.title: Millet Pilaf with Nuts
recipes.description: Aromatic millet pilaf with cinnamon and toasted nuts - serve hot or at room temperature.

instructions.text: Heat butter and olive oil in a heavy saucepan. Add onion; cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until soft and starting to color.
Add cinnamon and millet; cook for 2 to 3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Pour in water or stock; add salt and white pepper. Bring to a boil, cover and cook over very low heat for about 25 minutes, until the millet is tender and all the liquid has been absorbed.
Uncover and let sit for a few minutes to let the steam escape, then fluff with a fork.
Heat vegetable oil in a small skillet; add nuts. When they start to turn golden, remove pan from heat, lift nuts out with a slotted spoon and drain on absorbent paper.
With a fork, stir half of the nuts through the millet pilaf, then sprinkle the remaining nuts over the top.
Serve hot with a vegetable accompaniment such as beans in tomato sauce. In warm weather, serve the pilaf at room temperature with a salad such as tomato and spring onion.

notes: Vegetable stock is easily obtained by reserving the water used to cook vegetables for your daily meals

recipes.title: Creme de Menthe (Homemade)
recipes.description: Homemade mint liqueur that steeps for 10 days - smooth and refreshing.

instructions.text: Combine vodka, mint essence or extract and mint leaves.
Steep 10 days in a cool, dark place.
Strain through cheesecloth.
Add syrup and glycerine, if used.
Let rest overnight before serving.

notes: Glycerine adds body and smoothness to homemade liqueurs
Add green food coloring if desired

recipes.title: Hoppin' George
recipes.description: A twist on traditional Hoppin' John using pearled barley instead of rice with black-eyed peas.

ingredients.item: bacon bits or chopped cooked bacon

instructions.text: Saute onion and barley in oil until barley is slightly brown, about 5 to 7 minutes.
Add black-eyed peas, stock, bacon and salt.
Cover tightly and simmer until tender, about 1 hour.

notes: Traditional Southern New Year's dish variant
Barley adds a chewy, nutty texture different from rice

recipes.title: Alegria (Amaranth Candy)
recipes.description: Traditional Mexican candy made with popped amaranth seeds coated in honey and molasses.

ingredients.item: vegetable oil or nonstick cooking spray
light molasses or dark corn syrup

instructions.text: Pop amaranth by placing in a very hot skillet 1 tablespoon at a time, stirring constantly for about 15 seconds until seeds pop.
After they pop, transfer to a shallow bowl and add the next tablespoon of amaranth to the skillet. (You should have about 2 cups of popped grain.)
Lightly coat a 9-by-13-inch pan with oil.
Combine honey, molasses and butter in a large saucepan or skillet; bring slowly to a boil.
Cook over medium heat 5 to 7 minutes, stirring constantly, until mixture turns golden brown and becomes thick and sticky.
Add popped amaranth; stir with wooden spoon until amaranth is coated with syrup.
Transfer to 9-by-13-inch pan, gently pushing mixture into corners.
Let cool; cut into bars.

recipes.temperature: Stovetop - very hot skillet for popping
notes: Alegria means 'joy' in Spanish
Traditional Mexican street candy
Work quickly as the syrup hardens fast

recipes.title: Quinoa with Dried Cherries and Cashews
recipes.description: Colorful quinoa salad with orange dressing, saffron, dried cherries and toasted cashews.

instructions.text: Whisk together olive oil, orange juice, orange zest, 1 tablespoon mint, and salt and pepper to taste. Set aside.
Bring water to a boil in a medium saucepan over high heat. Add quinoa and saffron, stir well.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer until quinoa is tender and water is absorbed, about 15 minutes. [RECONSTRUCTED - standard quinoa cooking method]

recipes.title: Egg Substitutes for Baking
recipes.content: If you are one egg short when baking a cake, substitute one teaspoon of cornstarch instead.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: Easy egg replacements when you're out of eggs or need an egg-free option.
recipes.tip_text: Replace each egg with: 1/4 cup applesauce (for dense baked goods), 1/4 cup mashed banana, 1/4 cup plain yogurt, 1 tbsp ground flax + 3 tbsp water (let sit 5 min), or 1 tsp baking soda + 1 tbsp vinegar.

instructions.text: For binding: Use flax egg or chia egg (1 tbsp ground seeds + 3 tbsp water, let gel for 5 minutes).
For moisture: Use 1/4 cup mashed banana or applesauce per egg.
For leavening: Use 1/4 cup plain yogurt or buttermilk per egg.

recipes.title: Prevent Mold on Cheese
recipes.content: Do you want to prevent mold from growing on cheese? Wrap it tightly with a sugar cube and store it in the refrigerator. If your cheese is already moldy, simply wipe it off with a vinegar-soaked paper towel. The cheese will then be edible, and the flavor won't be affected.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: Keep cheese fresh longer by preventing mold growth.
recipes.tip_text: Wrap cheese in a paper towel dampened with vinegar before storing in plastic wrap. The acid prevents mold. Alternatively, rub a light coat of butter on cut surfaces of hard cheese.

instructions.text: Dampen a paper towel with white vinegar.
Wrap the cheese in the vinegar-dampened paper towel.
Place in an airtight container or wrap in plastic wrap.
Replace the paper towel every few days.

flags: [RECONSTRUCTED] Tip content added based on common kitchen knowledge

recipes.title: Use Potato to Grease Pans
recipes.content: Are you out of oil and need to grease a skillet? Rub it with half a potato. Pans "greased" with potato don't smoke at high temperatures like oiled pans do.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: A natural way to grease baking pans without butter or oil.
recipes.tip_text: Cut a raw potato in half and rub the cut side on your baking pan. The starch provides a natural non-stick coating that works well for breads and baked goods.

instructions.text: Cut a raw potato in half.
Rub the cut side over the entire inside surface of your baking pan.
Proceed with your recipe as usual.

flags: [RECONSTRUCTED] Tip content added based on common kitchen knowledge

recipes.title: Keep Brown Sugar Soft
recipes.content: Does your brown sugar harden like a concrete block? To keep it soft, store it in a glass jar in your refrigerator or in a plastic bag with a piece of bread or apple inside.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: Prevent brown sugar from hardening into a solid rock.
recipes.tip_text: Place a slice of bread or a marshmallow in your brown sugar container - the sugar draws moisture from it and stays soft. A dampened paper towel on foil works too. For hardened sugar, microwave with a damp paper towel for 20 seconds.

instructions.text: Store brown sugar in an airtight container.
Add a slice of bread, a marshmallow, or a terra cotta brown sugar saver.
If sugar hardens, place a damp paper towel over it and microwave for 20 seconds.
Replace the bread slice weekly for best results.

flags: [RECONSTRUCTED] Tip content added based on common kitchen knowledge

recipes.title: Bay Leaves Repel Pantry Insects
recipes.content: Don't let insects ruin your dry foods! Put a bay leaf into containers of pasta, flour, rice and dry mixes to keep them away.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: A natural way to keep bugs out of flour, rice, and other dry goods.
recipes.tip_text: Place dried bay leaves in containers of flour, rice, pasta, and other dry goods. The eucalyptol in bay leaves naturally repels weevils, flour beetles, and pantry moths. Replace leaves monthly.

instructions.text: Place 1-2 dried bay leaves directly into your flour, rice, or grain containers.
Tape fresh bay leaves inside pantry cabinets for broader protection.
Replace bay leaves monthly or when they lose their scent.

flags: [RECONSTRUCTED] Tip content added based on common kitchen knowledge

recipes.title: Rescue Broken Mayonnaise
recipes.content: If your mayonnaise separates or curdles, mix 1 teaspoon mustard and 1 tablespoon curdled mayonnaise in a bowl. Beat it with a wire whisk until it is creamy. Add the rest of the mayonnaise slowly and blend well.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: How to fix mayonnaise that has separated or curdled.
recipes.tip_text: Whisk a fresh egg yolk in a clean bowl, then slowly drizzle in the broken mayo while whisking constantly. The fresh yolk re-emulsifies the sauce. Alternatively, add 1-2 tsp boiling water and whisk vigorously.

instructions.text: Place a fresh egg yolk in a clean, dry bowl.
Whisk the yolk constantly while slowly adding the broken mayo, a little at a time.
Continue until all mayo is incorporated and smooth.
Alternative: Whisk 1-2 tsp boiling water into the broken mayo.

recipes.title: Prevent Cut Fruit from Browning
recipes.content: To keep a fresh fruit salad from turning brown, sprinkle the sliced fruit with lemon juice.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: Keep sliced apples, pears, and other fruits from turning brown.
recipes.tip_text: Toss cut fruit in lemon juice or dip in cold water with 1/2 tsp citric acid per cup. The acid prevents oxidation. For apples, a brief soak in lemon-lime soda works too.

instructions.text: Squeeze fresh lemon juice over cut fruit immediately after slicing.
For larger batches, soak fruit in cold water with 2 tbsp lemon juice per quart.
Drain and pat dry before serving or using in recipes.

recipes.title: Fix Lumpy Sugar
recipes.content: Is your granulated sugar lumpy? Place several saltine crackers in the container and cover it tightly.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: Restore clumped granulated sugar to its original texture.
recipes.tip_text: Break up clumped sugar by processing briefly in a food processor or blender. For white sugar, you can also heat it in a low oven (200°F) for 15 minutes and then break apart. Store in airtight containers to prevent future clumping.

instructions.text: For small clumps, break apart with a fork or whisk.
For larger clumps, pulse briefly in a food processor or blender.
Store sugar in airtight containers to prevent moisture absorption.

recipes.title: Using Frozen Dried-Out Cheese
recipes.content: If you have a block of cheese that has dried out, don't throw it away! Store it in freezer. When you need to grate it for a recipe, slice it thinly, without thawing. Frozen cheese crumbles easily. It is perfect for making macaroni and cheese.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: How to use cheese that has dried out or been frozen.
recipes.tip_text: Dried-out or frozen cheese works great grated into sauces, soups, and casseroles where it will melt. Freeze hard cheese blocks and grate directly from frozen - it's easier to grate and won't clump.

instructions.text: Freeze hard cheese for easier grating.
Grate dried-out cheese and use in sauces, soups, or casseroles where it melts.
Add frozen grated cheese directly to hot dishes - it melts quickly.

recipes.title: Freshen Dried-Out Coconut
recipes.content: Do you need to freshen dried out coconut? Place it in a strainer over a steaming pot of water for a few minutes.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: Restore moisture to dried or stale shredded coconut.
recipes.tip_text: Steam dried coconut over boiling water for 2-3 minutes, or soak in warm milk for 10 minutes and drain. This restores moisture and freshness to stale shredded coconut.

instructions.text: Place dried coconut in a steamer basket over boiling water.
Steam for 2-3 minutes until softened.
Alternatively, soak in warm milk for 10 minutes, then drain well.

recipes.title: Refresh Stale Bread
recipes.content: If you don't want to throw out a stale loaf of bread, sprinkle it with water or milk and wrap it in aluminum foil. Bake it at 350 degrees for about 8 minutes to soften it. Loaves of Italian or French bread need to be baked for 3-5 minutes more, with the foil open for the last few minutes.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 42.jpeg
recipes.description: Bring life back to day-old or stale bread.
recipes.tip_text: Run stale bread under water briefly, then heat in a 350°F oven for 5-10 minutes. The steam from the water revives the crust. For softer bread, wrap in damp paper towel and microwave 10 seconds.

instructions.text: Run stale bread quickly under water (don't soak).
Place directly on oven rack at 350°F for 5-10 minutes.
The steam refreshes the crust while the heat warms the interior.

recipes.title: Fix Sticky or Gummy Rice
recipes.content: Sticky rice? Rinse it thoroughly with warm water to wash out the excess starch. This will cause the grains to easily separate.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 43.jpeg
recipes.description: How to rescue rice that turned out too sticky.
recipes.tip_text: Rinse cooked sticky rice under cold water to remove excess starch, then spread on a baking sheet and dry in a 300°F oven for 5 minutes. For future batches, rinse rice before cooking and use less water.

instructions.text: Rinse sticky rice under cold water to remove excess starch.
Spread on a baking sheet lined with parchment.
Dry in a 300°F oven for 5-10 minutes, stirring once.
Prevention: Always rinse rice before cooking and reduce water slightly.

recipes.title: Fix Sticky Pasta
recipes.content: Sticky pasta? Add salt or oil to noodles while the water is boiling.

recipes.description: Rescue pasta that has stuck together in a clump.
recipes.tip_text: Toss sticky pasta with a little olive oil or butter to separate. If severely stuck, briefly dip in boiling water for 30 seconds, then drain and toss with oil. Use plenty of water when cooking pasta to prevent sticking.

instructions.text: Toss clumped pasta with 1-2 tbsp olive oil and stir to separate.
If severely stuck, briefly return to boiling water for 30 seconds.
Drain immediately and toss with oil or butter.
Prevention: Use large pot with plenty of water, stir immediately after adding pasta.

recipes.title: Rescue Over-Salted Food
recipes.content: Did you over-salt a recipe? Add a little vinegar and sugar and then taste. If it is a recipe for stew or soup, add a raw potato to absorb the excess salt.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 43.jpeg
recipes.description: How to fix dishes with too much salt.
recipes.tip_text: For soups/stews: dilute with unsalted broth or water. For other dishes: add dairy (cream, yogurt), acid (lemon juice, vinegar), or a touch of sugar to balance. Serve with unsalted rice or bread to offset saltiness.

instructions.text: For soups and stews, add more unsalted liquid (broth, water, cream).
Add a splash of acid (lemon juice or vinegar) to balance the salt taste.
Stir in a small amount of sugar or honey to counteract saltiness.
Serve with unsalted starches (plain rice, bread, pasta) to offset salt.

recipes.title: Fix Too-Sweet Dishes
recipes.content: Does your recipe have too much sugar? Add a few drops of lemon juice or vinegar.
notes: Original typed/printed source removed after transcription: Grandmas-recipes - 43.jpeg
recipes.description: How to balance overly sweet food.
recipes.tip_text: Balance excess sweetness with acid (lemon juice, vinegar), salt (a pinch reduces perceived sweetness), or bitter ingredients (cocoa powder, coffee). For baked goods, serve with unsweetened whipped cream.

instructions.text: Add acid: a squeeze of lemon juice or splash of vinegar cuts sweetness.
Add a small pinch of salt - it reduces the perception of sweetness.
For desserts, add bitter element like dark cocoa or espresso.
Serve overly sweet baked goods with unsweetened cream or plain yogurt.

recipes.title: Tofu Techniques

Cut tofu into 1/2-inch slices. Turn, slice into 1/2-inch strips, then into uniform cubes.

notes: These techniques work for extra-firm tofu used in stir-fries and other dishes.

recipes.title: Food Safety Tips - Power Outage
recipes.description: Don't Touch That Door! What to do when the power goes out.

instructions.text: If the power goes out, food will remain chilled for up to 6 hours as long as you don't open the refrigerator door.
Butter, margarine, hard or processed cheeses, and fresh vegetables and fruits will keep at room temperature for a few days; other perishables should be discarded.
Food in a full, closed freezer will be O.K. for about 2 days; a half-full freezer roughly 1 day.

recipes.title: Fruit and Cream Pie Tips
recipes.description: Tips for making fruit and cream pies with graham cracker crust.

instructions.text: Press graham cracker-butter mixture into bottom and up sides of pie plate.
Bake; let cool slightly. Use spatula to spread cream cheese mixture over bottom. Refrigerate.
Bring gelatin, pudding mix and water to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring constantly.
Arrange sliced fruit in decorative circles over cream cheese mixture; let pieces overlap slightly.

recipes.title: Cookie Making Tips
recipes.description: Tips for baking perfect cookies.

instructions.text: Use shiny aluminum baking sheets without sides for golden brown cookies.
Turn on your oven to the required temperature 10-15 minutes before baking.
If a recipe states to grease the baking sheets, use shortening for best results.
For even baking, make cookies the same size and thickness.
Leave at least 2 inches around the baking sheet and the oven walls for good heat circulation. For best results, bake only one sheet of cookies at a time.

Fold in Cool Whip.
Pour into graham cracker crust.

recipes.description: A dump cake-style berry cobbler with an oat and walnut crumb topping.

Mix until crumbly.
Sprinkle half of the mixture into the prepared pan.

recipes.title: Dump Cake

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).

recipes.title: Magic Mayonnaise
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook. GRANDMA'S FAVORITE - noted in her handwritten index.
recipes.description: A creamy homemade mayonnaise that keeps well in the refrigerator.

instructions.text: Beat condensed milk, pepper, dry mustard, salt, and Accent together until well blended.
Add in order: salad oil, then vinegar or lemon juice, then eggs.
Beat all together until well blended.
Store in refrigerator.
Good on tossed salad, coleslaw, etc.

recipes.title: Chops N' Sauerkraut
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook. GRANDMA'S FAVORITE - noted on front cover as 'Try pg 26 - Kraut + P. Chops'
recipes.description: Pork chops with sauerkraut - one of Grandma's most-loved recipes.

instructions.text: Brown pork chops and season with salt.
Saute potatoes and onion; add salt.
Layer pork chops on bottom of casserole.
Cover with potatoes and onion and then sauerkraut.
Add 1 cup water.
Cook over medium heat until potatoes are tender, about 45 minutes.
Serve with little bread or green vegetables.

notes: GRANDMA'S TOP FAVORITE - She wrote 'Try pg 26 - Kraut + P. Chops' on the front cover of her cookbook.
This was clearly a dish she made often for the family.

recipes.title: Stuffed Mushrooms
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook. GRANDMA'S FAVORITE - noted as 'Stuffed Mushrooms pg 2' in her index.

instructions.text: Gently wash mushrooms. Pull off stems and set caps aside.
Dice stems in small pieces and mix with bread crumbs.
Boil sausage, then dice split skin and take out meat.
Crumble meat, mushroom stems and crumbs and blend well with melted butter or margarine.
Saute till cooked.
Stuff all these ingredients into the mushroom caps.
Put a dot of butter on top of each one and place under broiler for 2-3 min.

notes: GRANDMA'S FAVORITE - noted in her handwritten index as 'Stuffed Mushrooms pg 2'

recipes.title: Cheese Ball
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook, page 1.

instructions.text: Put in bowl and let soften.
Beat together and then add 3 tbsp wine vinegar and a pinch of salt.
Beat together well.
Shape into 1 or 2 balls and roll in nuts.
Leave uncovered for 1/2 hour or more.

recipes.title: Chinese Chicken Wings
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook, page 1.

instructions.text: Disjoint wings (remove tips).
Mix soy sauce, lemon juice, honey and garlic; add wings.
Cover and marinate in refrigerator overnight (10-12 hours), turning occasionally.
Bake skin side down at 350°F for 15 min.
Broil a little on each side to brown and crispen.

recipes.title: Hors D'Ouevres (Clam)
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook, page 1.

Drain clams, add to mixture.
Spoon on melba toast sheet 1 inch high.
Place on foil-lined baking sheet.
Broil quickly until golden.

recipes.title: Roasted Pumpkin Seeds
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook, page 1.

instructions.text: Mix all so that seeds are coated.
Spread in a single layer on a cookie sheet.
Toast in oven at 350° until lightly gold and crisp.
Cool.

recipes.title: Hot Bacon-Cheese Spread
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook, page 1.

instructions.text: Put all ingredients through meat grinder.
Spread on 'party' rye.
Bake 5-8 min. at 400° until cheese starts to melt.

recipes.title: Veal Piccata
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook, page 26.

instructions.text: Sprinkle veal with salt and pepper. Dust lightly with flour.
Melt half of butter and oil in skillet.
Add veal and cook until brown.
Add wine and let evaporate. Pour off fat.
Add remaining butter and lemon juice.
Stir, scraping brown bits from bottom of pan.
Heat 3-5 min.
Garnish with lemon wedge, serve with risotto or fettuccine.

recipes.title: Veal & Pork Noodle Dish
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook, page 26.

instructions.text: Brown meat and onion.
Add celery, green pepper, soup and a little water.
Simmer until meat is tender.
Add noodles, corn and cheese.
Bake 30 min at 350°F.

recipes.title: Cooking Tips (Page 26)
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook, page 26.

instructions.text: Don't ever wash fish under running water. Takes away the flavor. Wipe it with a wrung-out cloth, dipped first in salted water.
Hard boiled eggs washed first under cold water before placing them in the boiling water, won't crack.

Spaghetti and/or noodles won't boil over if you rub the top inside edge of the cooking vessel with a little butter or margarine. A lump of the same tossed into the cooking water accomplishes this purpose, too.
A pinch of sugar is the best perker-up of any vegetable. Not enough to taste it. It does wonders for flavor.

recipes.title: Pastitsio (Greek Casserole)
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' - Our Lady of the Rosary Parish cookbook, page 23. GRANDMA'S FAVORITE - noted in her handwritten index as 'Greek casserole pg 23'.

instructions.text: In large skillet cook beef, onion and garlic until meat is browned and onion is tender.
Add tomatoes, 1/2 tsp salt, pepper and cinnamon; simmer 15 min.
Stir in 1/2 cup cheese and macaroni. Turn into 13x9x2 inch baking dish set aside.
In medium saucepan melt butter; blend in flour and remaining 1/4 tsp salt.
Gradually stir in milk and cook and stir until sauce thickens.
Cool slightly. Beat in eggs one at a time.
Stir in remaining 1/2 cup cheese and pour over meat mixture.
Place in preheated 350°F oven and bake 35-40 min or until golden brown and knife comes out clean.
Makes 6-8 servings.

notes: GRANDMA'S FAVORITE - noted in her handwritten index as 'Greek casserole pg 23'

recipes.title: Grandma's Chicken Cheese Ball
recipes.source_note: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN RECIPE - Found on inside cover of 'Specialties of the House' cookbook. This is Grandma's own personal recipe in her handwriting.

instructions.text: Soften cream cheese good.
Mix in boned chicken.
Add 1 pkg ranch dressing.
Make into ball.
Put plastic in bowl, put mix in, and tie up.

notes: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN RECIPE - This is Grandma's own personal recipe written in her handwriting on the inside cover of the cookbook. Has canonical precedence.

recipes.title: Baked Eggplant Parmigiana
recipes.source_note: Newspaper clipping (c) New York Times, found in 'Specialties of the House' cookbook inside cover.

ingredients.item: to 5 tablespoons butter at room temperature
Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste

instructions.text: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees.
Peel the eggplant and trim off the ends.
Cut the eggplant into 6 to 8 slices, each about 1/2-inch thick.
Blend the butter and cheese and spread the eggplant slices on both sides with the mixture.
Sprinkle with salt and pepper.
Arrange the slices on a baking sheet in 1 layer.
Bake 15 to 20 minutes or until eggplant is tender throughout.
Serve sprinkled with chopped parsley.
Yields 4 servings.

notes: Newspaper clipping from New York Times, found in Grandma's cookbook

recipes.title: Oatmeal Macaroons
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' cookbook, page 41. GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTE: 'Needs more flour as is'

instructions.text: Sift flour, powder, soda and salt together.
Combine sugars and oil; add egg; beat until well blended.
Add sifted dry ingredients, mix well.
Stir in remaining ingredients.
Shape into 1" balls. Place 3" apart on ungreased cookie sheet.
Bake at 350°F for 8-10 min.
Makes about 3 dozen.

notes: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTE: 'Needs more flour as is' - her variation suggestion

recipes.title: Molasses Sugar Cookies
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' cookbook, page 41. GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTES: '1/2C' and 'Same as Crinkles'

instructions.text: Cream together shortening and sugar. Add molasses and egg; beat well.
Sift together flour, soda, cinnamon, cloves, ginger and salt; add to creamed sugar mixture.
Mix well; chill.
Form into 1" balls, roll in granulated sugar and place on greased cookie sheets.
Bake at 350°F for 8-10 min.
Makes 5 doz.

notes: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTES: '1/2C' (possibly referring to an ingredient adjustment) and 'Same as Crinkles' - comparing to another recipe she knows

recipes.title: Peanut Butter Cookies
recipes.source_note: From 'Specialties of the House' cookbook, page 42. GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTE: 'more soda'

instructions.text: Cream together sugars, shortening and peanut butter.
Add eggs, sift flour, soda and salt; add to first mixture and mix well.
Roll into balls and place on slightly greased baking sheet.
Flatten with fork.
Bake 10-12 min at 375°F.

notes: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTE: 'more soda' - her variation for better results

recipes.title: Food for the Gods
recipes.source_note: From 'Centennial Recipes 1886-1986' - Calvary Lutheran Church, Elk Rapids MI, page 35. GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN 'TRY' next to recipe title - one of her favorites to try!

instructions.text: Beat eggs until fluffy, gradually add sugar.
Stir in graham cracker crumbs.
Mix in baking powder, dates and nuts.
Pour into lightly greased 9x13 inch pan and bake 25-30 minutes at 350 degrees.
Cool and serve with whipped cream or ice cream.
Serves 12.

notes: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN 'TRY' written next to this recipe - marked as something she wanted to make

recipes.title: Grandmother's Pound Cake
recipes.source_note: From 'Centennial Recipes 1886-1986' - Calvary Lutheran Church, Elk Rapids MI, page 35.

instructions.text: Pan size: Loaf pan, buttered and floured
Temperature: 300 degrees
Length of cooking time: 1 1/2 hours
Work butter until creamy, beat in sugar and eggs, one at a time.
Add flavoring. When creamy, fold in flour with spoon.
Spread in buttered and floured loaf pan.
Bake at 300 degrees for 1 1/2 hours.
Serves 8-10.

recipes.title: Cooking with Honey - Information & Tips
recipes.source_note: From 'My Favorite Honey Recipes' booklet. GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTES: checkmarks next to tips and 'Lower oven Temp' at bottom.

instructions.text: When measuring honey, moisten cup or spoon with oil or melted butter, or measure shortening before measuring honey.
To use honey in place of sugar substitute equal amount of honey, but reduce other liquid by 1/4 cup.
Cakes or cookies made with honey are improved in keeping qualities as honey tends to retard drying out, which is an important factor in baking in advance.
It is well to lower baking temperature of oven about 25 degrees which prevents over-browning of honey baked goods.

notes: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTES: Checkmarks next to tips she approved, and 'Lower oven Temp' written at bottom - her reminder about the temperature adjustment

recipes.title: Honey Date Spice Cake
recipes.source_note: From 'My Favorite Honey Recipes' booklet. GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTE: '1/2 water' - her modification. Book given to Elsie Wilson from Helen Hancock.

instructions.text: Cream together shortening and sugar.
Add eggs, one at a time, beating after each addition.
Gradually add honey; stir in dates and orange rind.
Sift together flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt and spices.
Blend into creamed mixture alternately with orange juice.
Bake in tube pan about 1 hour and fifteen minutes at 350°F.
Cool.

notes: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTE: '1/2 water' next to recipe - her modification
Book inscription: 'Elsie Wilson from Helen Hancock - The Honey Book'

recipes.title: Honey Spice Cake
recipes.source_note: From 'My Favorite Honey Recipes' booklet. GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTE: 'Ask Mary' - she wanted to ask someone about this recipe.

instructions.text: Cream shortening and honey.
Add two well-beaten eggs.
Sift flour twice, add soda and spices.
Gradually add milk and dry ingredients alternately into the creamed mixture.
Bake at 350°F in large loaf pan.

notes: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN NOTE: 'Ask Mary' - she wanted to consult someone named Mary about this recipe

instructions.text: Cream butter; blend in cottage cheese, flour and salt.
Beat in honey, lemon juice and rind.
Add egg yolks, one at a time, beating well after each addition.
Beat egg whites until stiff. Slowly add sugar; beat until peaks form.
Fold into cheese mixture. Blend in milk.
Combine all ingredients for Crumb Crust. Press all but 1/2 cup mixture firmly along bottom and sides of 11 1/2 x 7 1/2 x 1 1/2 pan.
Pour in filling; sprinkle with remaining crumb mixture.
Bake in 350°F oven 1 hour.
Chill for easier cutting.
Cream butter and honey.
Sift together flour, soda, and spices and mix in wheat germ.
Combine dry ingredients into creamed mixture.
Chill about one hour.
Roll on lightly floured board to about 1/8 inch thickness.
Cut with floured cookie cutter.
Bake on greased cookie sheets in 350 oven, 8-10 minutes.
Cool on rack, then spread thinly with frosting.
Makes about 3 dozen.

recipes.title: Honey Fruit Cookies
recipes.source_note: From 'My Favorite Honey Recipes' booklet. Memphis Beekeepers Assoc.

instructions.text: Cream shortening and honey, add the egg, sour milk, and flour which has been sifted with soda and salt.
Add the nuts and fruit.
Drop on greased pans and bake at 350°F for 12 minutes.

notes: Recipe from Memphis Beekeepers Association

recipes.title: Grandma's Impossible Pie (without Bisquick)
recipes.source_note: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN RECIPE - Written on appreciation page of 'Centennial Recipes 1886-1986' cookbook. This is her personal variation of Impossible Pie that doesn't require Bisquick. One of her favorites noted in her index as 'Imp Pie'.

instructions.text: [PARTIAL RECIPE - Grandma wrote key modifications at top of appreciation page]
This appears to be her modified ingredient list for making Impossible Pie without Bisquick.
The full method would follow standard Impossible Pie preparation.

notes: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN RECIPE - This is her personal creation written in her handwriting on the Centennial cookbook's appreciation page.
She titled it 'Impossible Pie (without Bisquick)' - showing she adapted the recipe to not require Bisquick mix.
Listed in her index as 'Imp Pie' - one of her favorites.
Has canonical precedence as a handwritten original.

flags: partial-recipe

recipes.title: Chops N'Sauerkraut
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, Our Lady of the Rosary Parish
recipes.description: Pork chops baked with sauerkraut and potatoes - one of Grandma's favorites she marked 'Try pg 26'

instructions.text: Brown pork chops, then set aside.
Saute onions until golden in drippings.
Layer sauerkraut and pork chops in pot.
Add water and seasonings.
Cover and cook over medium heat.
Add potatoes for last 30 min or until potatoes are tender.
Serve with cooking juices.

notes: GRANDMA'S FAVORITE - She wrote 'Try pg 26' and 'Kraut + P. Chops' on cookbook cover
From Specialties of the House cookbook, Our Lady of the Rosary Parish, Limited Edition #13

recipes.title: Grandma's Cheese Ball
recipes.source_note: Handwritten by Grandma on inside cover of Specialties cookbook
recipes.description: Grandma's own cheese ball recipe with chicken and ranch dressing

instructions.text: Soften cream cheese well.
Mix in boned chicken.
Add 1 pkg ranch dressing.
Make into ball.
Wrap in plastic and refrigerate.
Tie up and serve.

notes: GRANDMA'S HANDWRITTEN RECIPE - Found in her own handwriting on inside cover of Specialties cookbook
Has canonical precedence as a handwritten original

recipes.title: Pastitsio (Greek Casserole)
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, Our Lady of the Rosary Parish
recipes.description: Greek pasta casserole with ground beef and bechamel - one of Grandma's favorites

instructions.text: In large skillet cook beef, onion and garlic until meat is browned and onion is tender.
Add tomatoes, 1/2 tsp salt, pepper and cinnamon; simmer 15 min.
Stir in 1/4 cup cheese and macaroni. Turn into 13x9x2 inch baking dish; set aside.
In medium saucepan melt butter; blend in flour.
Gradually stir in milk and cook and stir until sauce thickens.
Beat in eggs one at a time.
Stir in remaining 1/4 cup cheese and pour over meat mixture.
Bake at 375°F for 35-40 min or until golden brown and knife comes out clean.

notes: GRANDMA'S FAVORITE - Listed on her handwritten index (blue sticky note) as 'Greek Casserole pg 23'
From Specialties of the House cookbook. Makes 6-8 servings.

recipes.title: Cheese Ball
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, Our Lady of the Rosary Parish, p.1

instructions.text: Put in bowl and let soften.
Beat together well.
Then add 3 tbsp wine vinegar and a pinch of salt.
Shape into 1 or 2 balls and roll in nuts.
Uncovered for 1/2 hour or more.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.1

recipes.title: Hors D'ouvres
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, Our Lady of the Rosary Parish, p.1

instructions.text: Mash cream cheese, blend with garlic, Worcestershire and salt; beat till soft.
Drain clams, add to mixture.
Spoon on melba toast sheet 1 inch high.
Place on foil-lined baking sheet.
Broil quickly until golden.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.1

recipes.title: Hot Bacon-Cheese Spread
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, Our Lady of the Rosary Parish, p.1

instructions.text: Put all ingredients through meat grinder.
Spread on party rye.
Bake 5-8 min at 400°F until cheese starts to melt.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.1

recipes.title: Quiche Lorraine
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, Our Lady of the Rosary Parish, p.2

instructions.text: Fry bacon till crisp, drain.
Put on bottom of pie shell, add grated cheese.
Mix only till blended, with cream, eggs and spices.
Pour on top of cheeses.
Bake for 50-60 minutes at 375°F.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.2

recipes.title: Stuffed Clams
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, Our Lady of the Rosary Parish, p.2

instructions.text: Saute onion and celery in one level tablespoon of butter or margarine.
Mix all ingredients together and add 1/4 cup clam juice to make it moist.
Fill shells and place in broiler pan with water in bottom for approximately 10 min until browned.
NOTE: Shells must not lay in water.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.2

recipes.title: Eggplant in Vinegar
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes

ingredients.prep_note: cut into small cubes or slices
cloves of garlic, fresh, peeled or unpared

ingredients.item: Well packed in quart jar and add only white vinegar

instructions.text: Cut eggplant into small cubes or slices, peeled or unpared.
Place in pot and sauerkraut mixture with vinegar.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes section

recipes.title: Marinated Kraut
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes

instructions.text: Mix kraut, green pepper, onion and pimentos.
Mix remaining ingredients, pour over kraut mixture.
Let stand several hours or overnight.
Dip into serving dish. Serves 8.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes section

recipes.title: Pepper Relish
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes

instructions.text: Chop or grind peppers and onion.
Cover with boiling water, let stand for 5 min.
Add vinegar, sugar and salt.
Boil mixture 5 min.
Pour into jars, seal.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes section

recipes.title: Pickled Green Tomatoes
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes

instructions.text: Place small tomatoes in quart jars, add 3 cloves of garlic.
Fill jars with half water and half white vinegar, add 1 tbsp salt.
Leave uncovered for a few days, then cover and set aside.
Ready in 6-8 weeks.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes section

recipes.title: Pickle Japanures
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes

instructions.text: Wash and remove stems of Spanish peppers.
Place in pot and barely cover with water.
Boil 10 min. Pour off water.
Add all ingredients in a jar and add vinegar to cover.
Ready in one week.
The carrot sticks are hot and crisp.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes section

recipes.title: Spiced Mixed Olives
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes

instructions.text: Drain liquid from ripe olives and discard.
Drain liquid from stuffed olives and reserve.
Put both kinds of olives in a jar.
Add garlic, bay leaves, mustard seeds, thyme and salt and pepper to reserved liquid, add to fill jar, adding water to cover.
Refrigerate till needed. Makes 1 pint.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.3 - Relishes section

recipes.title: Hot Spiced Apple Cider
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.4 - Beverages

instructions.text: Put cider in saucepan. Put cinnamon sticks and cloves in a small cheesecloth bag.
Add to cider. Add rest of ingredients.
Cover and heat slowly to boiling point, about 20 min.
Remove from heat. Before serving, remove spice bag.
Serves 10.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.4 - Beverages section

recipes.title: Sangria
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.4 - Beverages

instructions.text: Squeeze lime and orange into pitcher, add sugar and cinnamon.
Add brandy and wine, then soda and ice cubes.
Stir and garnish with fruit slices.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.4 - Beverages section

recipes.title: Kahlua (Homemade)
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.4 - Beverages

instructions.text: Mix water and coffee; add sugar and stir till dissolved.
Add vodka or brandy and place in 1/2 gallon bottle.
Place vanilla bean in bottle with mixture.
Cap tightly.
Shake well daily for 25 to 30 days.
Mixture improves with age, but remove vanilla bean after 60 days.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.4 - Beverages section
Homemade coffee liqueur

recipes.title: Egg Nog
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.4 - Beverages

instructions.text: Separate eggs; beat yolks in a large bowl.
Add sugar gradually. Add milk, 3 cups at a time, mixing well between additions.
Add whiskey, rum and cognac.
This mixture may be stored in refrigerator up to one week.
When ready to serve, add the following: egg whites (beat till stiff with a dash of sugar) and cream whipped to peaks with dash of sugar.
Shake together. Refrigerate at least 24 hours before serving.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.4 - Beverages section

recipes.title: Champagne Punch
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.4 - Beverages

instructions.text: Mix all well in large punch bowl.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.4 - Beverages section

recipes.title: Applesauce Spice Loaf
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.5 - Breads

instructions.text: Sift together flour, sugar, salt, soda, baking powder, cinnamon, cloves and allspice.
In mixing bowl, add applesauce, butter and water. Beat 2 min.
Add eggs, beat 3 min more.
Stir in raisins and nuts. Pour into greased and floured 9 x 5 loaf pan.
Bake at 350°F for 65 min.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.5 - Breads section

recipes.title: Biscuit Fan-Tans
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.5 - Breads

instructions.text: Sift together flour, 3 tbsp sugar, baking powder, cream of tartar, and salt into mixing bowl.
Cut in butter until mixture resembles peas, small pea size.
Add milk and stir with fork to moisten all ingredients.
Roll dough into a 12 x 5 inch rectangle, brush lightly with melted butter.
Cut into strips and stack, place in greased muffin pan.
Brush with melted butter. Combine 1/4 cup sugar and cinnamon, sprinkle over each.
Bake at 450°F for 15 min. Makes 12.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.5 - Breads section

recipes.title: Basic Dough
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.5 - Breads

instructions.text: Pour 2 cups hot water over powdered milk, sugar and oleo and cool to lukewarm.
Meanwhile, dissolve yeast in 1/2 cup warm water.
Combine with first mixture, add eggs and flour.
Beat very hard with mixer. Let rise until light.
Add enough flour to make a real soft dough.
Turn into greased bowl, cover with plastic wrap, place in refrigerator.
Check dough in an hour or so and knead down as necessary.
This dough can be used for doughnuts, rolls, sweetbread, etc.
Shape directly from refrigerator and let rise 1 1/2 to 2 hours before baking.

FOR DOUGHNUTS: Heat oil or shortening to 375°F, put doughnuts in grease with tops down. Fry about 1 1/2 min each side or until lightly brown. Turn only once. Drain on ungreased paper. Dip tops into glaze.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.5 - Breads section
GLAZE: Powdered sugar, Lemon extract, Hot water
Versatile dough for multiple uses

recipes.title: English Muffin Bread
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.6 - Breads

instructions.text: Combine 3 cups flour, yeast, sugar, salt and soda.
Add hot water and oil; blend on low speed of mixer and add eggs.
Beat 3 min. Stir in remaining flour to form stiff batter.
Spoon into 2 greased 8x4 inch loaf pans sprinkled with cornmeal.
Cover; let rise 45 min in warm place.
Bake at 400°F for 25 min. To serve, slice and toast.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.6 - Breads section

recipes.title: Banana Nut Bread
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.6 - Breads

instructions.text: Blend shortening and sugar; add egg and beat well.
Stir in All-Bran, bananas and vanilla.
Sift together flour, baking powder, soda and salt. Add to first mixture.
Add nuts; stir only until combined.
Spread in well-greased loaf pan. Bake at 350°F about one hour.

notes: GRANDMA MARKED 'Good' - One of her favorites!
From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.6 - Breads section

recipes.title: Cranberry Nut Bread
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.6 - Breads

instructions.text: Sift dry ingredients together.
Cut in shortening.
Combine egg and milk; add to flour mixture.
Stir just until moistened.
Fold in cranberries and nuts.
Pour into greased loaf pan. Bake at 350°F for 60 min.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.6 - Breads section

recipes.title: Dumplings
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.6 - Breads

ingredients.item: enough milk to keep dough together

instructions.text: Toast bread, cut into cubes and place in bowl.
Add flour, beaten eggs, baking powder and salt.
Then keep adding milk to form dough. Don't make it too wet, but just soft enough so you can drop it from a spoon into rapidly boiling, salted water.
Don't touch dumplings until formed, then you can turn them.
Cover pot, let boil approximately 10 min until a fork pierced through comes out clean.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.6 - Breads section

recipes.title: Basic Wine Jelly
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.7 - Jellies, Jams

instructions.text: Stir wine and sugar until thoroughly blended in glass saucepan, using a wooden spoon.
Set over direct heat (use heat diffuser best), stir and heat about 3 min.
Remove from heat, stir in liquid fruit pectin; continue stirring 5 min.
Skim off foam. Pour into small glass jars.
Cover and store. Ready to use in 6-8 weeks.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.7 - Jellies, Jams section

recipes.title: Kumquat Jam
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.7 - Jellies, Jams

instructions.text: Seed, then grind kumquats in 2 cups water.
Add equal parts water, and sugar.
Boil 45 min.
Cool, fill jars and seal.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.7 - Jellies, Jams section

recipes.title: Orange Marmalade
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.7 - Jellies, Jams

ingredients.item: water to each cup of pulp

instructions.text: Seed, core and chop 8 oranges.
Add 3 cups water to each cup of pulp.
Cook uncovered for 15 min or pressure cook at 15 lbs for 5 min.
Let stand overnight for marmalade, then use 3 cups stock to 1 cup sugar.
Cook rapidly, stirring occasionally until jelly stage (220°F).
Cool, ladle into sterile jars.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.7 - Jellies, Jams section

recipes.title: Rhubarb Marmalade
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.7 - Jellies, Jams

instructions.text: Combine rhubarb and sugar in heavy kettle.
Place over medium heat. Heat slowly, stirring until rhubarb becomes juicy and mixture starts to boil.
Boil 10 min, stirring constantly.
Remove from heat, stir in strawberry gelatin. Pour into hot jars.
Cool with tight lids. Keeps cool, store in refrigerator. Makes 2 pints.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.7 - Jellies, Jams section

recipes.title: Shrimp Sauce
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.8 - Sauces

instructions.text: Use your own judgment as to amounts of each ingredient.
Shake well to mix.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.8 - Sauces section

recipes.title: Spaghetti Sauce
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.8 - Sauces

instructions.text: Brown hamburger, salt and pepper. Put into separate dish.
Put garlic into pan and saute in fat.
Add tomato paste until it begins to stay together and seems to leave the bottom of the pan.
Add 2 qts of water, then add stewed tomatoes and rest of ingredients.
Cook 1/2 hr.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.8 - Sauces section

recipes.title: Sweet & Sour Sauce
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.8 - Sauces

instructions.text: Mix above ingredients together and heat.
Mix together 1 tbsp corn starch and one cup water and put into sauce.
OPTIONAL: They add about one diced green pepper, one cup pineapple chunks and one fresh chopped tomato.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.8 - Sauces section

recipes.title: Tartar Sauce
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.8 - Sauces

instructions.text: Just before serving, combine chilled mayonnaise with all other ingredients.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.8 - Sauces section

recipes.title: Marinated Bean Salad
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.9 - Salads

instructions.text: Drain all beans. Mix with pepper and onion.
Combine oil, vinegar, sugar, salt and pepper.
Pour over beans and refrigerate overnight.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.9 - Salads section

recipes.title: Candlestick Salad
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.9 - Salads

instructions.text: Place pineapple slice on lettuce leaf.
Stand half banana upright in center hole.
Top with cherry for the 'flame'.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.9 - Salads section
Fun presentation for children

recipes.title: Carrot Salad
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.9 - Salads

instructions.text: Combine carrots and raisins.
Mix mayonnaise, sugar and lemon juice.
Toss with carrot mixture.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.9 - Salads section

recipes.title: Congealed Salad
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.9 - Salads

instructions.text: Dissolve gelatin in hot water.
Cool until slightly thickened.
Fold in remaining ingredients.
Pour into mold and refrigerate until set.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.9 - Salads section

recipes.title: Festive Fruit Salad
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.9 - Salads

instructions.text: Combine all fruits, marshmallows and coconut.
Fold in sour cream.
Refrigerate several hours or overnight.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.9 - Salads section

recipes.title: Georgia Coleslaw
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.10 - Salads

instructions.text: Mix cabbage, pepper and onion.
Bring remaining ingredients to boil.
Pour over vegetables while hot.
Refrigerate overnight.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.10 - Salads section

recipes.title: Guacamole Bowl with Avocado Dressing
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.10 - Salads

instructions.text: Mash avocados with fork.
Blend in lemon juice, salt, pepper sauce and garlic.
Fold in sour cream.
Serve with tortilla chips.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.10 - Salads section

recipes.title: Hot Potato Salad
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.10 - Salads

instructions.text: Cook potatoes in skins, peel and slice while warm.
Fry bacon crisp, remove and crumble.
Saute onion in drippings.
Blend in flour, sugar and salt.
Add vinegar and water, cook until thick.
Pour over potatoes, add bacon.
Serve warm.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.10 - Salads section

recipes.title: Molded Egg Salad
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.10 - Salads

instructions.text: Soften gelatin in cold water, dissolve over hot water.
Blend into mayonnaise.
Fold in remaining ingredients.
Pour into mold and chill until firm.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.10 - Salads section

recipes.title: Raw Spinach Salad
recipes.source_note: Specialties of the House cookbook, p.10 - Salads

instructions.text: Wash spinach, remove stems, tear into pieces.
Add eggs and bacon.
Combine remaining ingredients for dressing.
Toss just before serving.

notes: From Specialties of the House cookbook, p.10 - Salads section

recipes.title: Refrigerator Cabbage Salad
